Projection Methods for Functional Equations

The Bellman optimality equation Lv=v\mathrm{L}v = vLv=v is a functional equation: an equation where the unknown is an entire function rather than a finite-dimensional vector. When the state space is continuous or very large, we cannot represent the value function exactly on a computer. We must instead work with finite-dimensional approximations. This motivates projection methods, a general framework for transforming infinite-dimensional problems into tractable finite-dimensional ones.

What Does It Mean for a Residual to Be Zero?¶

Suppose we have found a candidate approximate solution v^\hat{v}v^ to the Bellman equation. To verify it satisfies Lv^=v^\mathrm{L}\hat{v} = \hat{v}Lv^=v^, we compute the residual function R(s)=Lv^(s)−v^(s)R(s) = \mathrm{L}\hat{v}(s) - \hat{v}(s)R(s)=Lv^(s)−v^(s). For a true solution, this residual should be the zero function: R(s)=0R(s) = 0R(s)=0 for every state sss. But what does it really mean for a function to equal zero?

In finite dimensions, a vector r∈Rn\mathbf{r} \in \mathbb{R}^nr∈Rn equals zero if and only if ⟨r,y⟩=0\langle \mathbf{r}, \mathbf{y} \rangle = 0⟨r,y⟩=0 for every vector y∈Rn\mathbf{y} \in \mathbb{R}^ny∈Rn. This follows because if r≠0\mathbf{r} \neq \mathbf{0}r=0, we can always choose y=r\mathbf{y} = \mathbf{r}y=r, giving ⟨r,r⟩=∥r∥2>0\langle \mathbf{r}, \mathbf{r} \rangle = \|\mathbf{r}\|^2 > 0⟨r,r⟩=∥r∥2>0. Conversely, if r=0\mathbf{r} = \mathbf{0}r=0, then ⟨r,y⟩=0\langle \mathbf{r}, \mathbf{y} \rangle = 0⟨r,y⟩=0 trivially for all y\mathbf{y}y.

Inner products can distinguish the zero vector from any nonzero vector: for any r≠0\mathbf{r} \neq \mathbf{0}r=0, there exists some test vector y\mathbf{y}y that “witnesses” the fact that r\mathbf{r}r is nonzero by producing ⟨r,y⟩≠0\langle \mathbf{r}, \mathbf{y} \rangle \neq 0⟨r,y⟩=0. This property, that we can tell apart (separate) different vectors by testing them with inner products, is what makes inner products so useful for verification.

The same principle extends to functions. A function RRR equals the zero function if and only if its “inner product” with every “test function” ppp vanishes:

R=0if and only if⟨R,p⟩=∫SR(s)p(s)w(s)ds=0for all test functions p,R = 0 \quad \text{if and only if} \quad \langle R, p \rangle = \int_{\mathcal{S}} R(s) p(s) w(s) ds = 0 \quad \text{for all test functions } p,R=0if and only if⟨R,p⟩=∫S​R(s)p(s)w(s)ds=0for all test functions p,
(1)

where w(s)w(s)w(s) is a weight function (often chosen to emphasize certain regions of the state space). Why does this work? For the same reason as in finite dimensions: if RRR is not the zero function, there must be some region where R(s)≠0R(s) \neq 0R(s)=0. We can then choose a test function ppp that is nonzero in that same region (for instance, p(s)=R(s)p(s) = R(s)p(s)=R(s) itself), which will produce ⟨R,p⟩=∫R(s)p(s)w(s)ds>0\langle R, p \rangle = \int R(s) p(s) w(s) ds > 0⟨R,p⟩=∫R(s)p(s)w(s)ds>0, witnessing that RRR is nonzero. Conversely, if RRR is the zero function, then ⟨R,p⟩=0\langle R, p \rangle = 0⟨R,p⟩=0 for any test function ppp.

This ability to distinguish between different functions using inner products is a fundamental principle from functional analysis. Just as we can test a vector by taking inner products with other vectors, we can test a function by taking inner products with other functions.

Connection to Functional Analysis

The principle that “a function equals zero if and only if it has zero inner product with all test functions” is a consequence of the Hahn-Banach theorem, one of the cornerstones of functional analysis. The theorem guarantees that for any nonzero function RRR in a suitable function space, there exists a continuous linear functional (which can be represented as an inner product with some test function ppp) that produces a nonzero value when applied to RRR. This is often phrased as “the dual space separates points.”

While you don’t need to know the Hahn-Banach theorem to use projection methods, it provides the rigorous mathematical foundation ensuring that our inner product tests are theoretically sound. The constructive argument we gave above (choosing p=Rp = Rp=R) works in simple cases with well-behaved functions, but the Hahn-Banach theorem extends this guarantee to much more general settings.

Why is this useful? It transforms the pointwise condition “R(s)=0R(s) = 0R(s)=0 for all sss” (infinitely many conditions, one per state) into an equivalent condition about inner products. We still cannot test against all possible test functions, since there are infinitely many of those too. But the inner product perspective suggests a natural computational strategy: choose a finite collection of test functions {p1,…,pn}\{p_1, \ldots, p_n\}{p1​,…,pn​} and require

⟨R,pi⟩=0,i=1,…,n.\langle R, p_i \rangle = 0, \quad i = 1, \ldots, n.⟨R,pi​⟩=0,i=1,…,n.
(2)

This gives us exactly nnn conditions that we can actually compute. This approach defines what are called weighted residual methods: we make the residual “small” by requiring it to satisfy certain weighted integral conditions.

Within weighted residual methods, there are two main families:

Projection methods (also called orthogonal projection methods) directly require the residual to have zero inner product with chosen test functions:

⟨R,pi⟩=0,i=1,…,n.\langle R, p_i \rangle = 0, \quad i = 1, \ldots, n.⟨R,pi​⟩=0,i=1,…,n.
(3)

We are “projecting” the residual to be orthogonal to the span of the test functions. Different choices of test functions give different projection methods:

  • Galerkin: Test against the basis functions used to represent v^\hat{v}v^, so pi=φip_i = \varphi_ipi​=φi​

  • Collocation: Test against delta functions pi=δ(s−si)p_i = \delta(s - s_i)pi​=δ(s−si​), which reduces to pointwise evaluation R(si)=0R(s_i) = 0R(si​)=0

  • Method of moments: Test against polynomials pi=si−1p_i = s^{i-1}pi​=si−1, ensuring low-order moments of the residual vanish

  • Subdomain method: Test against indicator functions pi=IDip_i = I_{D_i}pi​=IDi​​ for subregions DiD_iDi​, requiring zero average residual in each subdomain

The Special Role of Spectral Methods¶

You may encounter the term spectral methods in the literature. This doesn’t refer to a different choice of test functions, but rather to a choice of basis functions φi\varphi_iφi​. Spectral methods use basis functions from families of orthogonal polynomials (like Chebyshev, Legendre, or Hermite polynomials) or trigonometric functions (Fourier series). The “spectral” name comes from the decomposition of the solution into these orthogonal components, analogous to decomposing a signal into frequency components.

What makes spectral bases special is their approximation properties: for smooth problems (functions with many continuous derivatives), spectral approximations achieve exponential convergence. As you add more basis functions, the approximation error decreases exponentially rather than polynomially. A function with kkk continuous derivatives approximated by piecewise polynomials of degree ppp has error O(hp+1)O(h^{p+1})O(hp+1) where hhh is the grid spacing. But the same function approximated by a spectral method with nnn terms has error that decreases like O(e−cn)O(e^{-cn})O(e−cn) for some constant c>0c > 0c>0. This dramatic difference makes spectral methods extremely efficient for smooth problems.

Now, spectral bases can be combined with any projection method. When we use a spectral basis with Galerkin projection (testing against the basis functions themselves), we get a spectral Galerkin method. The orthogonality of the basis functions often simplifies the resulting linear systems. When we use a spectral basis with collocation, we get what’s often called a pseudospectral method or spectral collocation method.

Orthogonal Collocation¶

Orthogonal collocation exploits a useful connection between collocation and quadrature. The idea is to:

  1. Choose basis functions from an orthogonal polynomial family (say, Chebyshev polynomials T0,T1,…,Tn−1T_0, T_1, \ldots, T_{n-1}T0​,T1​,…,Tn−1​)

  2. Choose collocation points at the zeros of the nnn-th polynomial in that family

Why is this clever? Because these same points are also the optimal nodes for Gauss quadrature using the weight function associated with that polynomial family. For example, the zeros of the Chebyshev polynomial Tn(s)T_n(s)Tn​(s) are also the Chebyshev-Gauss quadrature nodes. This means:

  • We get the computational simplicity of collocation: the projection conditions are just R(si)=0R(s_i) = 0R(si​)=0 at the collocation points (no integrals to evaluate)

  • When we do need to compute integrals (say, inside the operator N\mathscr{N}N itself), we can use the collocation points as quadrature nodes and the resulting quadrature is exact for polynomials up to degree 2n−12n-12n−1

  • For smooth problems, we inherit the exponential convergence of spectral approximations

This coordination between approximation and integration is why orthogonal collocation is so effective. You’ll sometimes see it called a “pseudospectral method,” though different authors use these terms with slight variations. The key point is that by carefully coordinating our choice of basis, test functions (collocation points), and quadrature nodes, we can achieve excellent accuracy with computational efficiency.

In summary, “spectral” describes the basis choice (orthogonal polynomials or Fourier), while “Galerkin,” “collocation,” etc. describe the projection choice (which test functions). Orthogonal collocation represents an optimal marriage of these choices for smooth problems.

Least squares methods take a different approach: instead of requiring orthogonality to specific test functions, we minimize the overall size of the residual measured in a weighted norm:

min⁡θ∥R(⋅;θ)∥2=min⁡θ∫SR(s;θ)2w(s)ds.\min_{\theta} \|R(\cdot; \theta)\|^2 = \min_{\theta} \int_{\mathcal{S}} R(s; \theta)^2 w(s) ds.θmin​∥R(⋅;θ)∥2=θmin​∫S​R(s;θ)2w(s)ds.
(4)

This seeks the coefficients θ\thetaθ that make the residual as small as possible in the least squares sense. The first-order optimality conditions for this minimization problem turn out to be equivalent to a projection method with test functions pi=∂R/∂θip_i = \partial R / \partial \theta_ipi​=∂R/∂θi​ (the derivatives of the residual with respect to the coefficients). So least squares can be viewed as a projection method with data-dependent test functions.

Both families aim to make the residual “close to zero,” but projection methods do this by requiring orthogonality to chosen directions, while least squares does this by directly minimizing the norm of the residual. The term “projection methods” as used in the approximate dynamic programming literature often refers to both families, since they share the same computational framework of restricting the search to a finite-dimensional subspace and solving for coefficients that satisfy certain residual conditions.

In summary, we have transformed the impossible task of verifying “R(s)=0R(s) = 0R(s)=0 for all sss” into a finite-dimensional problem: find coefficients θ=(θ1,…,θn)\theta = (\theta_1, \ldots, \theta_n)θ=(θ1​,…,θn​) in our approximation v^(s)=∑i=1nθiφi(s)\hat{v}(s) = \sum_{i=1}^n \theta_i \varphi_i(s)v^(s)=∑i=1n​θi​φi​(s) such that either:

  • The residual is orthogonal to nnn chosen test functions (projection methods), or

  • The residual has minimum norm (least squares methods)

This is a major conceptual step forward: instead of infinitely many pointwise conditions, we have nnn conditions. However, these nnn conditions are not yet fully “feasible” computationally. Each projection condition ⟨R,pi⟩=∫SR(s)pi(s)w(s)ds=0\langle R, p_i \rangle = \int_{\mathcal{S}} R(s) p_i(s) w(s) ds = 0⟨R,pi​⟩=∫S​R(s)pi​(s)w(s)ds=0 still involves an integral that may need to be approximated numerically.

The computational cost hierarchy. Different methods have different computational burdens:

  • Collocation is the cheapest: since ⟨R,δ(⋅−si)⟩=R(si)\langle R, \delta(\cdot - s_i) \rangle = R(s_i)⟨R,δ(⋅−si​)⟩=R(si​), we only evaluate the residual pointwise. No integration is needed in the projection conditions themselves.

  • Orthogonal collocation shares this advantage (projection conditions are just pointwise evaluations), but adds a bonus: if integrals appear elsewhere, say inside the operator N\mathscr{N}N, the collocation points double as optimal quadrature nodes. This synergy between approximation and integration is particularly valuable for smooth problems.

  • Galerkin methods require evaluating integrals ∫R(s)φi(s)w(s)ds\int R(s) \varphi_i(s) w(s) ds∫R(s)φi​(s)w(s)ds for each basis function. When using orthogonal polynomial bases (spectral Galerkin), these integrals can sometimes be simplified by orthogonality, but numerical quadrature is still typically needed.

  • Method of moments and subdomain methods similarly require numerical quadrature to evaluate weighted integrals of the residual.

  • Least squares requires computing ∫R(s)2w(s)ds\int R(s)^2 w(s) ds∫R(s)2w(s)ds, which involves integrating the squared residual. This is potentially expensive, though the first-order conditions reduce this to a system similar to Galerkin.

The general pattern: collocation methods avoid integration in the projection step by testing at points rather than against functions, while methods that test against smooth functions (Galerkin, moments, subdomain) must pay the computational cost of numerical integration.

The rest of this chapter develops this framework systematically, showing how to choose bases, select test functions, evaluate or approximate the necessary integrals, and solve the resulting finite-dimensional problems.

The General Framework¶

Consider an operator equation of the form

N(f)=0,\mathscr{N}(f) = 0,N(f)=0,
(5)

where N:B1→B2\mathscr{N}: B_1 \to B_2N:B1​→B2​ is a continuous operator between complete normed vector spaces B1B_1B1​ and B2B_2B2​. For the Bellman equation, we have N(v)=Lv−v\mathscr{N}(v) = \mathrm{L}v - vN(v)=Lv−v, so that solving N(v)=0\mathscr{N}(v) = 0N(v)=0 is equivalent to finding the fixed point v=Lvv = \mathrm{L}vv=Lv.

The projection method approach consists of several conceptual steps that transform this infinite-dimensional problem into a finite-dimensional one.

Step 1: Choose a Finite-Dimensional Approximation Space¶

We begin by selecting a basis Φ={φ1,φ2,…,φn}\Phi = \{\varphi_1, \varphi_2, \ldots, \varphi_n\}Φ={φ1​,φ2​,…,φn​} and approximating the unknown function as a linear combination:

f^(x)=∑i=1nθiφi(x).\hat{f}(x) = \sum_{i=1}^n \theta_i \varphi_i(x).f^​(x)=i=1∑n​θi​φi​(x).
(6)

The choice of basis functions φi\varphi_iφi​ is problem-dependent. Common choices include:

  • Polynomials: For smooth problems, we might use Chebyshev polynomials or other orthogonal polynomial families

  • Splines: For problems where we expect the solution to have regions of different smoothness

  • Radial basis functions: For high-dimensional problems where tensor product methods become intractable

The number of basis functions nnn determines the flexibility of our approximation. In practice, we start with small nnn and increase it until the approximation quality is satisfactory. The only unknowns now are the coefficients θ=(θ1,…,θn)\theta = (\theta_1, \ldots, \theta_n)θ=(θ1​,…,θn​).

While the classical presentation of projection methods focuses on polynomial bases, the framework applies equally well to other function classes. Neural networks, for instance, can be viewed through this lens: a neural network f^(x;θ)\hat{f}(x; \theta)f^​(x;θ) with parameters θ\thetaθ defines a flexible function class, and many training procedures can be interpreted as projection methods with specific choices of test functions or residual norms. The distinction is that classical methods typically use predetermined basis functions with linear coefficients, while neural networks use adaptive nonlinear features. Throughout this chapter, we focus on the classical setting to develop the core concepts, but the principles extend naturally to modern function approximators.

Step 2: Define the Residual Function¶

Since we are approximating fff with f^\hat{f}f^​, the operator N\mathscr{N}N will generally not vanish exactly. Instead, we obtain a residual function:

R(x;θ)=N(f^(⋅;θ))(x).R(x; \theta) = \mathscr{N}(\hat{f}(\cdot; \theta))(x).R(x;θ)=N(f^​(⋅;θ))(x).
(7)

This residual measures how far our candidate solution is from satisfying the equation at each point xxx. As we discussed in the introduction, we will assess whether this residual is “close to zero” by testing its inner products against chosen test functions.

Step 3: Choose Weighted Residual Conditions¶

Having chosen our basis and defined the residual, we must decide how to make the residual “close to zero.” As discussed in the introduction, we can either:

  1. Use projection conditions: Select nnn test functions {p1,…,pn}\{p_1, \ldots, p_n\}{p1​,…,pn​} and require:

    ⟨R(⋅;θ),pi⟩=∫SR(x;θ)pi(x)w(x)dx=0,i=1,…,n,\langle R(\cdot; \theta), p_i \rangle = \int_{\mathcal{S}} R(x; \theta) p_i(x) w(x) dx = 0, \quad i = 1, \ldots, n,⟨R(⋅;θ),pi​⟩=∫S​R(x;θ)pi​(x)w(x)dx=0,i=1,…,n,
    (8)

    for some weight function w(x)w(x)w(x). This yields nnn equations to determine the nnn coefficients in θ\thetaθ.

  2. Use a least squares condition: Minimize the norm of the residual directly:

    min⁡θ∫SR(x;θ)2w(x)dx.\min_\theta \int_{\mathcal{S}} R(x; \theta)^2 w(x) dx.θmin​∫S​R(x;θ)2w(x)dx.
    (9)

We begin by examining the main projection methods, distinguished entirely by their choice of test functions pip_ipi​, then discuss least squares as an alternative approach.

Let us examine the standard choices of test functions and what they tell us about the residual:

Galerkin Method: Test Against the Basis¶

The Galerkin method chooses test functions pi=φip_i = \varphi_ipi​=φi​, the same basis functions used to approximate f^\hat{f}f^​:

⟨R(⋅;θ),φi⟩=0,i=1,…,n.\langle R(\cdot; \theta), \varphi_i \rangle = 0, \quad i = 1, \ldots, n.⟨R(⋅;θ),φi​⟩=0,i=1,…,n.
(10)

To understand what this means, recall that in finite dimensions, two vectors are orthogonal when their inner product is zero. For functions, ⟨R,φi⟩=∫R(x)φi(x)w(x)dx=0\langle R, \varphi_i \rangle = \int R(x) \varphi_i(x) w(x) dx = 0⟨R,φi​⟩=∫R(x)φi​(x)w(x)dx=0 expresses the same concept: RRR and φi\varphi_iφi​ are orthogonal as functions. But there’s more to this than just testing against individual basis functions.

Consider our approximation space span{φ1,…,φn}\text{span}\{\varphi_1, \ldots, \varphi_n\}span{φ1​,…,φn​} as an nnn-dimensional subspace within the infinite-dimensional space of all functions. Any function ggg in this space can be written as g=∑i=1nciφig = \sum_{i=1}^n c_i \varphi_ig=∑i=1n​ci​φi​ for some coefficients cic_ici​. If the residual RRR is orthogonal to all basis functions φi\varphi_iφi​, then by linearity of the inner product, for any such function ggg:

⟨R,g⟩=⟨R,∑i=1nciφi⟩=∑i=1nci⟨R,φi⟩=0.\langle R, g \rangle = \left\langle R, \sum_{i=1}^n c_i \varphi_i \right\rangle = \sum_{i=1}^n c_i \langle R, \varphi_i \rangle = 0.⟨R,g⟩=⟨R,i=1∑n​ci​φi​⟩=i=1∑n​ci​⟨R,φi​⟩=0.
(11)

This shows that RRR is orthogonal to every function we can represent with our basis. The residual has “zero overlap” with our approximation space: we cannot express any part of it using our basis functions. In this sense, the residual is as “invisible” to our approximation as possible.

This condition is the defining property of optimality. By choosing our approximation f^\hat{f}f^​ so that the residual R=N(f^)R = \mathscr{N}(\hat{f})R=N(f^​) is orthogonal to the entire approximation space, we ensure that f^\hat{f}f^​ is the orthogonal projection of the true solution onto spanφ1,…,φn\text{span}{\varphi_1, \ldots, \varphi_n}spanφ1​,…,φn​. Within this nnn-dimensional space, no better choice is possible: any other coefficients would yield a residual with a nonzero component inside the space, and therefore a larger norm.

The finite-dimensional analogy makes this concrete. Suppose you want to approximate a vector v∈R3\mathbf{v} \in \mathbb{R}^3v∈R3 using only the xyxyxy-plane (a 2D subspace). The best approximation is to project v\mathbf{v}v onto the plane, giving v^=(v1,v2,0)\hat{\mathbf{v}} = (v_1, v_2, 0)v^=(v1​,v2​,0). The error is r=v−v^=(0,0,v3)\mathbf{r} = \mathbf{v} - \hat{\mathbf{v}} = (0, 0, v_3)r=v−v^=(0,0,v3​), which points purely in the zzz-direction, orthogonal to the entire xyxyxy-plane. We see the Galerkin condition in action: the error is orthogonal to the approximation space.

Method of Moments: Test Against Monomials¶

The method of moments, for problems on D⊂RD \subset \mathbb{R}D⊂R, chooses test functions pi(x)=xi−1p_i(x) = x^{i-1}pi​(x)=xi−1 for i=1,…,ni = 1, \ldots, ni=1,…,n:

⟨R(⋅;θ),xi−1⟩=0,i=1,…,n.\langle R(\cdot; \theta), x^{i-1} \rangle = 0, \quad i = 1, \ldots, n.⟨R(⋅;θ),xi−1⟩=0,i=1,…,n.
(12)

This requires the first nnn moments of the residual function to vanish, ensuring the residual is “balanced” in the sense that it has no systematic trend captured by low-order polynomials. The moments ∫xkR(x;θ)w(x)dx\int x^k R(x; \theta) w(x) dx∫xkR(x;θ)w(x)dx measure weighted averages of the residual, with increasing powers of xxx giving more weight to larger values. Setting these to zero ensures the residual doesn’t grow systematically with xxx. This approach is particularly useful when w(x)w(x)w(x) is chosen as a probability measure, making the conditions natural moment restrictions familiar from statistics and econometrics.

Collocation Method: Test Against Delta Functions¶

The collocation method chooses test functions pi(x)=δ(x−xi)p_i(x) = \delta(x - x_i)pi​(x)=δ(x−xi​), the Dirac delta functions at points {x1,…,xn}\{x_1, \ldots, x_n\}{x1​,…,xn​}:

⟨R(⋅;θ),δ(⋅−xi)⟩=R(xi;θ)=0,i=1,…,n.\langle R(\cdot; \theta), \delta(\cdot - x_i) \rangle = R(x_i; \theta) = 0, \quad i = 1, \ldots, n.⟨R(⋅;θ),δ(⋅−xi​)⟩=R(xi​;θ)=0,i=1,…,n.
(13)

This is projection against the most localized test functions possible: delta functions that “sample” the residual at specific points, requiring the residual to vanish exactly where we test it. When using orthogonal polynomials with collocation points at the zeros of the nnn-th polynomial, the Chebyshev interpolation theorem guarantees that forcing R(xi;θ)=0R(x_i; \theta) = 0R(xi​;θ)=0 at these specific points makes R(x;θ)R(x; \theta)R(x;θ) small everywhere. Using the zeros of orthogonal polynomials as collocation points produces well-conditioned systems and near-optimal interpolation error. The computational advantage is significant. Collocation avoids numerical integration entirely, requiring only pointwise evaluation of RRR.

Subdomain Method: Test Against Indicator Functions¶

The subdomain method partitions the domain into nnn subregions {D1,…,Dn}\{D_1, \ldots, D_n\}{D1​,…,Dn​} and chooses test functions pi=IDip_i = I_{D_i}pi​=IDi​​, the indicator functions:

⟨R(⋅;θ),IDi⟩=∫DiR(x;θ)w(x)dx=0,i=1,…,n.\langle R(\cdot; \theta), I_{D_i} \rangle = \int_{D_i} R(x; \theta) w(x) dx = 0, \quad i = 1, \ldots, n.⟨R(⋅;θ),IDi​​⟩=∫Di​​R(x;θ)w(x)dx=0,i=1,…,n.
(14)

This requires the residual to have zero average over each subdomain, ensuring the approximation is good “on average” over each piece of the domain. This approach is particularly natural for finite element methods where the domain is divided into elements, ensuring local balance of the residual within each element.

Least Squares¶

The least squares approach appears different at first glance, but it also fits the test function framework. We minimize:

min⁡θ∫SR(x;θ)2w(x)dx=min⁡θ⟨R(⋅;θ),R(⋅;θ)⟩.\min_\theta \int_{\mathcal{S}} R(x; \theta)^2 w(x) dx = \min_\theta \langle R(\cdot; \theta), R(\cdot; \theta) \rangle.θmin​∫S​R(x;θ)2w(x)dx=θmin​⟨R(⋅;θ),R(⋅;θ)⟩.
(15)

The first-order conditions for this minimization problem are:

⟨R(⋅;θ),∂R(⋅;θ)∂θi⟩=0,i=1,…,n.\left\langle R(\cdot; \theta), \frac{\partial R(\cdot; \theta)}{\partial \theta_i} \right\rangle = 0, \quad i = 1, \ldots, n.⟨R(⋅;θ),∂θi​∂R(⋅;θ)​⟩=0,i=1,…,n.
(16)

Thus least squares implicitly uses test functions pi=∂R/∂θip_i = \partial R / \partial \theta_ipi​=∂R/∂θi​, the gradients of the residual with respect to parameters. Unlike other methods where test functions are chosen a priori, here they depend on the current guess for θ\thetaθ and on the structure of our approximation.

We can now see the unifying structure of weighted residual methods: whether we use projection conditions or least squares minimization, all these methods follow the same template of restricting the search to an nnn-dimensional function space and imposing nnn conditions on the residual. For projection methods specifically, we pick nnn test functions and require ⟨R,pi⟩=0\langle R, p_i \rangle = 0⟨R,pi​⟩=0. They differ only in their philosophy about which test functions best detect whether the residual is “nearly zero.” Galerkin tests against the approximation basis itself (natural for orthogonal bases), the method of moments tests against monomials (ensuring polynomial balance), collocation tests against delta functions (pointwise satisfaction), subdomain tests against indicators (local average satisfaction), and least squares tests against residual gradients (global norm minimization). Each choice reflects different priorities: computational efficiency, theoretical optimality, ease of implementation, or sensitivity to errors in different regions of the domain.

Step 4: Solve the Finite-Dimensional Problem¶

The projection conditions give us a system to solve for the coefficients θ\thetaθ. For test function methods (Galerkin, collocation, moments, subdomain), we solve:

Pi(θ)≡⟨R(⋅;θ),pi⟩=0,i=1,…,n.P_i(\theta) \equiv \langle R(\cdot; \theta), p_i \rangle = 0, \quad i = 1, \ldots, n.Pi​(θ)≡⟨R(⋅;θ),pi​⟩=0,i=1,…,n.
(17)

This is a system of nnn (generally nonlinear) equations in nnn unknowns. For least squares, we solve the optimization problem min⁡θ⟨R(⋅;θ),R(⋅;θ)⟩\min_\theta \langle R(\cdot; \theta), R(\cdot; \theta) \rangleminθ​⟨R(⋅;θ),R(⋅;θ)⟩.

The conditioning of the system depends on the choice of test functions. The Jacobian matrix has entries:

Jij=∂Pi∂θj=⟨∂R(⋅;θ)∂θj,pi⟩.J_{ij} = \frac{\partial P_i}{\partial \theta_j} = \left\langle \frac{\partial R(\cdot; \theta)}{\partial \theta_j}, p_i \right\rangle.Jij​=∂θj​∂Pi​​=⟨∂θj​∂R(⋅;θ)​,pi​⟩.
(18)

When test functions are orthogonal (or nearly so), the Jacobian tends to be well-conditioned. This is why orthogonal polynomial bases are preferred in Galerkin methods: they produce Jacobians with controlled condition numbers.

The computational cost per iteration varies significantly:

  • Collocation: Cheapest to evaluate since Pi(θ)=R(xi;θ)P_i(\theta) = R(x_i; \theta)Pi​(θ)=R(xi​;θ) requires only pointwise evaluation (no integration). The Jacobian is also cheap: Jij=∂R(xi;θ)∂θjJ_{ij} = \frac{\partial R(x_i; \theta)}{\partial \theta_j}Jij​=∂θj​∂R(xi​;θ)​.

  • Galerkin and moments: More expensive due to integration. Computing Pi(θ)=∫R(x;θ)pi(x)w(x)dxP_i(\theta) = \int R(x; \theta) p_i(x) w(x) dxPi​(θ)=∫R(x;θ)pi​(x)w(x)dx requires numerical quadrature. Each Jacobian entry requires integrating ∂R∂θjpi\frac{\partial R}{\partial \theta_j} p_i∂θj​∂R​pi​.

  • Least squares: Most expensive when done via the objective function, which requires integrating R2R^2R2. However, the first-order conditions reduce it to a system like Galerkin, with test functions pi=∂R/∂θip_i = \partial R / \partial \theta_ipi​=∂R/∂θi​.

For methods requiring integration, the choice of quadrature rule should match the basis. Gaussian quadrature with nodes at orthogonal polynomial zeros is efficient. When combined with collocation at those same points, the quadrature is exact for polynomials up to a certain degree. This coordination between quadrature and collocation makes orthogonal collocation effective.

The choice of solver depends on whether the finite-dimensional approximation preserves the structural properties of the original infinite-dimensional problem. This matters for the Bellman equation, where the original operator L\mathrm{L}L is a contraction.

Successive approximation (fixed-point iteration) is the natural choice when the original operator is a contraction, as it preserves the global convergence guarantees. However, the finite-dimensional approximation L^\hat{\mathrm{L}}L^ may not inherit the contraction property of L\mathrm{L}L. The approximation can introduce spurious fixed points or destroy the contraction constant, leading to divergence or slow convergence. This is especially problematic when using high-order polynomial approximations, which can create artificial oscillations that destabilize the iteration.

Newton’s method is often the default choice for projection methods because it doesn’t rely on the contraction property. Instead, it exploits the smoothness of the residual function. When the original problem is smooth and the approximation preserves this smoothness, Newton’s method provides quadratic convergence near the solution. However, Newton’s method requires good initial guesses and may converge to spurious solutions if the finite-dimensional problem has multiple fixed points that the original problem lacks.

The choice of basis and projection method affects which algorithm is most appropriate. For example:

  • Linear interpolation often preserves contraction properties, making successive approximation reliable

  • High-order polynomials may destroy contraction but provide smooth approximations suitable for Newton’s method

  • Shape-preserving splines can maintain both smoothness and structural properties

In practice, which algorithm should we use? When the operator equation can be written as a fixed-point problem f=Tff = \mathscr{T}ff=Tf and the operator T\mathscr{T}T is known to be a contraction, successive approximation is often the best starting point: it is computationally cheap and globally convergent. However, not all equations N(f)=0\mathscr{N}(f) = 0N(f)=0 admit a natural fixed-point reformulation, and even when they do (e.g., f=f−αN(f)f = f - \alpha \mathscr{N}(f)f=f−αN(f) for some α>0\alpha > 0α>0), the resulting operator may not be a contraction in the finite-dimensional approximation space. In such cases, Newton’s method becomes the primary option despite its requirement for good initial guesses and higher computational cost per iteration. A hybrid approach often works well: use successive approximation when applicable to generate an initial guess, then switch to Newton’s method for refinement.

Another consideration is the conditioning of the resulting system. Poorly chosen basis functions or collocation points can lead to nearly singular Jacobians, causing numerical instability. Orthogonal bases and carefully chosen collocation points (like Chebyshev nodes) are preferred because they tend to produce well-conditioned systems.

Step 5: Verify the Solution¶

Once we have computed a candidate solution f^\hat{f}f^​, we must verify its quality. Projection methods optimize f^\hat{f}f^​ with respect to specific criteria (specific test functions or collocation points), but we should check that the residual is small everywhere, including directions or points we did not optimize over.

Typical diagnostic checks include:

  • Computing ∥R(⋅;θ)∥\|R(\cdot; \theta)\|∥R(⋅;θ)∥ using a more accurate quadrature rule than was used in the optimization

  • Evaluating R(x;θ)R(x; \theta)R(x;θ) at many points not used in the fitting process

  • If using Galerkin with the first nnn basis functions, checking orthogonality against higher-order basis functions

Application to the Bellman Equation¶

We now apply the projection method framework to the Bellman optimality equation. Recall that we seek a function vvv satisfying

v(s)=Lv(s)=max⁡a∈As{r(s,a)+γ∑j∈Sp(j∣s,a)v(j)}.v(s) = \mathrm{L}v(s) = \max_{a \in \mathcal{A}_s} \left\{ r(s,a) + \gamma \sum_{j \in \mathcal{S}} p(j|s,a) v(j) \right\}.v(s)=Lv(s)=a∈As​max​⎩⎨⎧​r(s,a)+γj∈S∑​p(j∣s,a)v(j)⎭⎬⎫​.
(19)

Writing this as an operator equation N(v)=0\mathscr{N}(v) = 0N(v)=0 with N(v)=Lv−v\mathscr{N}(v) = \mathrm{L}v - vN(v)=Lv−v, the residual function for a candidate approximation v^(s)=∑i=1nθiφi(s)\hat{v}(s) = \sum_{i=1}^n \theta_i \varphi_i(s)v^(s)=∑i=1n​θi​φi​(s) is:

R(s;θ)=Lv^(s)−v^(s)=max⁡a∈As{r(s,a)+γ∑j∈Sp(j∣s,a)v^(j)}−∑i=1nθiφi(s).R(s; \theta) = \mathrm{L}\hat{v}(s) - \hat{v}(s) = \max_{a \in \mathcal{A}_s} \left\{ r(s,a) + \gamma \sum_{j \in \mathcal{S}} p(j|s,a) \hat{v}(j) \right\} - \sum_{i=1}^n \theta_i \varphi_i(s).R(s;θ)=Lv^(s)−v^(s)=a∈As​max​⎩⎨⎧​r(s,a)+γj∈S∑​p(j∣s,a)v^(j)⎭⎬⎫​−i=1∑n​θi​φi​(s).
(20)

Any of the projection methods we discussed (Galerkin, method of moments, collocation, subdomain, or least squares) can be applied here. Each would give us nnn conditions to determine the nnn coefficients in our approximation. For instance:

  • Galerkin would require ⟨R(⋅;θ),φi⟩=0\langle R(\cdot; \theta), \varphi_i \rangle = 0⟨R(⋅;θ),φi​⟩=0 for i=1,…,ni = 1, \ldots, ni=1,…,n, involving integration of the residual weighted by basis functions

  • Method of moments would require ⟨R(⋅;θ),si−1⟩=0\langle R(\cdot; \theta), s^{i-1} \rangle = 0⟨R(⋅;θ),si−1⟩=0, setting the first nnn moments of the residual to zero

  • Collocation would require R(si;θ)=0R(s_i; \theta) = 0R(si​;θ)=0 at nnn chosen states, forcing the residual to vanish pointwise

In practice, collocation is the most commonly used projection method for the Bellman equation. The reason is computational: collocation avoids the numerical integration required by Galerkin and method of moments. Since the Bellman operator already involves integration (or summation) over next states, adding another layer of integration for the projection conditions would be computationally expensive. Collocation sidesteps this by requiring the equation to hold exactly at specific points.

We focus on collocation in detail, though the principles extend to other projection methods.

Collocation for the Bellman Equation¶

The collocation approach chooses nnn states {s1,…,sn}\{s_1, \ldots, s_n\}{s1​,…,sn​} (the collocation points) and requires:

R(si;θ)=0,i=1,…,n.R(s_i; \theta) = 0, \quad i = 1, \ldots, n.R(si​;θ)=0,i=1,…,n.
(21)

This gives us a system of nnn nonlinear equations in nnn unknowns:

∑j=1nθjφj(si)=max⁡a∈Asi{r(si,a)+γ∑j∈Sp(j∣si,a)v^(j)},i=1,…,n.\sum_{j=1}^n \theta_j \varphi_j(s_i) = \max_{a \in \mathcal{A}_{s_i}} \left\{ r(s_i,a) + \gamma \sum_{j \in \mathcal{S}} p(j|s_i,a) \hat{v}(j) \right\}, \quad i = 1, \ldots, n.j=1∑n​θj​φj​(si​)=a∈Asi​​max​⎩⎨⎧​r(si​,a)+γj∈S∑​p(j∣si​,a)v^(j)⎭⎬⎫​,i=1,…,n.
(22)

The right-hand side requires evaluating the Bellman operator at the collocation points. For each collocation point sis_isi​, we must:

  1. For each action a∈Asia \in \mathcal{A}_{s_i}a∈Asi​​, compute the expected continuation value ∑j∈Sp(j∣si,a)v^(j)\sum_{j \in \mathcal{S}} p(j|s_i,a) \hat{v}(j)∑j∈S​p(j∣si​,a)v^(j)

  2. Take the maximum over actions

When the state space is continuous, the expectation involves integration, which typically requires numerical quadrature. When the state space is discrete but large, this is a straightforward (though potentially expensive) summation.

Solving the Collocation System¶

To organize our thinking about solution methods, it helps to introduce the collocation Bellman operator B:Rn→Rn\mathcal{B}: \mathbb{R}^n \to \mathbb{R}^nB:Rn→Rn, which maps coefficient vectors to target values at the collocation points. Given a coefficient vector θ=(θ1,…,θn)\theta = (\theta_1, \ldots, \theta_n)θ=(θ1​,…,θn​), the iii-th component is defined as:

[B(θ)]i=max⁡a∈Asi{r(si,a)+γ∑j∈Sp(j∣si,a)∑ℓ=1nθℓφℓ(j)}.[\mathcal{B}(\theta)]_i = \max_{a \in \mathcal{A}_{s_i}} \left\{ r(s_i, a) + \gamma \sum_{j \in \mathcal{S}} p(j|s_i, a) \sum_{\ell=1}^n \theta_\ell \varphi_\ell(j) \right\}.[B(θ)]i​=a∈Asi​​max​⎩⎨⎧​r(si​,a)+γj∈S∑​p(j∣si​,a)ℓ=1∑n​θℓ​φℓ​(j)⎭⎬⎫​.
(23)

In words: [B(θ)]i[\mathcal{B}(\theta)]_i[B(θ)]i​ is the value obtained by applying the Bellman operator at collocation point sis_isi​, using the approximation v^(s;θ)=∑ℓ=1nθℓφℓ(s)\hat{v}(s; \theta) = \sum_{\ell=1}^n \theta_\ell \varphi_\ell(s)v^(s;θ)=∑ℓ=1n​θℓ​φℓ​(s) in place of the true value function. This is equivalently written as [B(θ)]i=[Lv^(⋅;θ)](si)[\mathcal{B}(\theta)]_i = [\mathrm{L}\hat{v}(\cdot; \theta)](s_i)[B(θ)]i​=[Lv^(⋅;θ)](si​), emphasizing that we evaluate the Bellman operator L\mathrm{L}L applied to the parametric approximation at the collocation points. The operator B\mathcal{B}B evaluates the right-hand side of the Bellman equation at all collocation points, given a current guess for the coefficients.

Let Φ\boldsymbol{\Phi}Φ denote the n×nn \times nn×n collocation matrix with entries Φij=φj(si)\Phi_{ij} = \varphi_j(s_i)Φij​=φj​(si​). The left-hand side of the collocation equations is Φθ\boldsymbol{\Phi} \thetaΦθ, which gives the values of v^(si;θ)\hat{v}(s_i; \theta)v^(si​;θ) at the collocation points. The collocation equation requires these to match:

Φθ=B(θ).\boldsymbol{\Phi} \theta = \mathcal{B}(\theta).Φθ=B(θ).
(24)

This is the fixed-point problem we need to solve. We can approach it in two fundamentally different ways: as a fixed-point iteration (function iteration) or as a rootfinding problem (Newton’s method).

Method 1: Function Iteration (Successive Approximation)¶

We can rewrite the collocation equation as θ=Φ−1B(θ)\theta = \boldsymbol{\Phi}^{-1} \mathcal{B}(\theta)θ=Φ−1B(θ) (assuming Φ\boldsymbol{\Phi}Φ is invertible, which holds when the basis functions are linearly independent at the collocation points). This suggests the function iteration scheme:

θ(k+1)=Φ−1B(θ(k)).\theta^{(k+1)} = \boldsymbol{\Phi}^{-1} \mathcal{B}(\theta^{(k)}).θ(k+1)=Φ−1B(θ(k)).
(25)

This iteration has an intuitive interpretation when we break it into two steps:

Step 1 (Apply Bellman operator): For the current coefficient guess θ(k)\theta^{(k)}θ(k), compute the Bellman operator values at all collocation points:

ti(k)=[B(θ(k))]i=max⁡a∈Asi{r(si,a)+γ∑j∈Sp(j∣si,a)∑ℓ=1nθℓ(k)φℓ(j)},i=1,…,n.t_i^{(k)} = [\mathcal{B}(\theta^{(k)})]_i = \max_{a \in \mathcal{A}_{s_i}} \left\{ r(s_i, a) + \gamma \sum_{j \in \mathcal{S}} p(j|s_i, a) \sum_{\ell=1}^n \theta^{(k)}_\ell \varphi_\ell(j) \right\}, \quad i = 1, \ldots, n.ti(k)​=[B(θ(k))]i​=a∈Asi​​max​⎩⎨⎧​r(si​,a)+γj∈S∑​p(j∣si​,a)ℓ=1∑n​θℓ(k)​φℓ​(j)⎭⎬⎫​,i=1,…,n.
(26)

We now have a vector of targets t(k)=(t1(k),…,tn(k))=B(θ(k))t^{(k)} = (t_1^{(k)}, \ldots, t_n^{(k)}) = \mathcal{B}(\theta^{(k)})t(k)=(t1(k)​,…,tn(k)​)=B(θ(k)).

Step 2 (Fit to targets): Find new coefficients θ(k+1)\theta^{(k+1)}θ(k+1) such that the approximation matches the targets at the collocation points:

∑ℓ=1nθℓ(k+1)φℓ(si)=ti(k),i=1,…,n.\sum_{\ell=1}^n \theta^{(k+1)}_\ell \varphi_\ell(s_i) = t_i^{(k)}, \quad i = 1, \ldots, n.ℓ=1∑n​θℓ(k+1)​φℓ​(si​)=ti(k)​,i=1,…,n.
(27)

In matrix form: Φθ(k+1)=t(k)\boldsymbol{\Phi} \theta^{(k+1)} = t^{(k)}Φθ(k+1)=t(k), which gives θ(k+1)=Φ−1t(k)=Φ−1B(θ(k))\theta^{(k+1)} = \boldsymbol{\Phi}^{-1} t^{(k)} = \boldsymbol{\Phi}^{-1} \mathcal{B}(\theta^{(k)})θ(k+1)=Φ−1t(k)=Φ−1B(θ(k)).

This is parametric value iteration or projection-based value iteration: we iterate the Bellman operator in the finite-dimensional coefficient space, projecting back onto the span of the basis functions at each step. The method:

  • Separates the nonlinear optimization (maximization in the Bellman operator) from the linear fitting problem

  • Is globally convergent when the finite-dimensional approximation preserves the contraction property

  • Requires only solving a linear system Φθ(k+1)=t(k)\boldsymbol{\Phi} \theta^{(k+1)} = t^{(k)}Φθ(k+1)=t(k) at each iteration

Handling Stochastic Expectations

When the model includes a continuous random variable (e.g., s′=g(s,a,ϵ)s' = g(s, a, \epsilon)s′=g(s,a,ϵ) where ϵ\epsilonϵ is a random disturbance, often called a “shock” in economics and econometrics), we must approximate the expectation using numerical quadrature. We replace the continuous ϵ\epsilonϵ with a discrete approximation taking values {ϵ1,…,ϵm}\{\epsilon_1, \ldots, \epsilon_m\}{ϵ1​,…,ϵm​} with probabilities {w1,…,wm}\{w_1, \ldots, w_m\}{w1​,…,wm​}. The collocation Bellman operator becomes:

[B(θ)]i=max⁡a∈Asi{r(si,a)+γ∑k=1mwk∑ℓ=1nθℓφℓ(g(si,a,ϵk))}.[\mathcal{B}(\theta)]_i = \max_{a \in \mathcal{A}_{s_i}} \left\{ r(s_i, a) + \gamma \sum_{k=1}^m w_k \sum_{\ell=1}^n \theta_\ell \varphi_\ell(g(s_i, a, \epsilon_k)) \right\}.[B(θ)]i​=a∈Asi​​max​{r(si​,a)+γk=1∑m​wk​ℓ=1∑n​θℓ​φℓ​(g(si​,a,ϵk​))}.
(28)

Common quadrature schemes include Gauss-Hermite (for normal random variables), Gauss-Legendre (for uniform random variables), or sparse grids for high-dimensional random variables.

Method 2: Newton’s Method with the Envelope Theorem¶

Alternatively, we can write the collocation equation as a rootfinding problem:

F(θ)≡Φθ−B(θ)=0.F(\theta) \equiv \boldsymbol{\Phi} \theta - \mathcal{B}(\theta) = 0.F(θ)≡Φθ−B(θ)=0.
(29)

Newton’s method for this system uses the update:

θ(k+1)=θ(k)−JF(θ(k))−1F(θ(k)),\theta^{(k+1)} = \theta^{(k)} - J_F(\theta^{(k)})^{-1} F(\theta^{(k)}),θ(k+1)=θ(k)−JF​(θ(k))−1F(θ(k)),
(30)

where JF(θ)J_F(\theta)JF​(θ) is the Jacobian of FFF at θ\thetaθ. Since JF=Φ−JBJ_F = \boldsymbol{\Phi} - J_{\mathcal{B}}JF​=Φ−JB​ where JBJ_{\mathcal{B}}JB​ is the Jacobian of the collocation Bellman operator B\mathcal{B}B, we can rewrite this as:

θ(k+1)=θ(k)−[Φ−JB(θ(k))]−1[Φθ(k)−B(θ(k))].\theta^{(k+1)} = \theta^{(k)} - [\boldsymbol{\Phi} - J_{\mathcal{B}}(\theta^{(k)})]^{-1} [\boldsymbol{\Phi} \theta^{(k)} - \mathcal{B}(\theta^{(k)})].θ(k+1)=θ(k)−[Φ−JB​(θ(k))]−1[Φθ(k)−B(θ(k))].
(31)

The main challenge now is computing the Jacobian JB(θ)J_{\mathcal{B}}(\theta)JB​(θ). The (i,j)(i,j)(i,j)-th entry is:

[JB]ij=∂[B(θ)]i∂θj=∂∂θj[max⁡a∈Asi{r(si,a)+γ∑k∈Sp(k∣si,a)∑ℓ=1nθℓφℓ(k)}].[J_{\mathcal{B}}]_{ij} = \frac{\partial [\mathcal{B}(\theta)]_i}{\partial \theta_j} = \frac{\partial}{\partial \theta_j} \left[ \max_{a \in \mathcal{A}_{s_i}} \left\{ r(s_i, a) + \gamma \sum_{k \in \mathcal{S}} p(k|s_i, a) \sum_{\ell=1}^n \theta_\ell \varphi_\ell(k) \right\} \right].[JB​]ij​=∂θj​∂[B(θ)]i​​=∂θj​∂​[a∈Asi​​max​{r(si​,a)+γk∈S∑​p(k∣si​,a)ℓ=1∑n​θℓ​φℓ​(k)}].
(32)

At first glance, this appears problematic because the max operator is not differentiable. However, we can apply the Envelope Theorem to compute this derivative without dealing with the non-differentiability of the max operator.

The Envelope Theorem

Setup: Consider a smooth objective function f(x,θ)f(\mathbf{x}, \boldsymbol{\theta})f(x,θ) and define the optimal value:

v(θ)=max⁡xf(x,θ).v(\boldsymbol{\theta}) = \max_{\mathbf{x}} f(\mathbf{x}, \boldsymbol{\theta}).v(θ)=xmax​f(x,θ).
(33)

Let x(θ)\mathbf{x}(\boldsymbol{\theta})x(θ) denote the maximizer, satisfying the first-order condition:

∇xf(x(θ),θ)=0.\nabla_{\mathbf{x}} f(\mathbf{x}(\boldsymbol{\theta}), \boldsymbol{\theta}) = \mathbf{0}.∇x​f(x(θ),θ)=0.
(34)

The Result: To find how the optimal value changes with θ\boldsymbol{\theta}θ, write v(θ)=f(x(θ),θ)v(\boldsymbol{\theta}) = f(\mathbf{x}(\boldsymbol{\theta}), \boldsymbol{\theta})v(θ)=f(x(θ),θ) and apply the chain rule:

∇θv(θ)=∇θf(x(θ),θ)⏟direct effect+∇xf(x(θ),θ)⊤⏟0 at optimum∂x∂θ.\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} v(\boldsymbol{\theta}) = \underbrace{\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} f(\mathbf{x}(\boldsymbol{\theta}), \boldsymbol{\theta})}_{\text{direct effect}} + \underbrace{\nabla_{\mathbf{x}} f(\mathbf{x}(\boldsymbol{\theta}), \boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top}}_{\mathbf{0} \text{ at optimum}} \frac{\partial \mathbf{x}}{\partial \boldsymbol{\theta}}.∇θ​v(θ)=direct effect∇θ​f(x(θ),θ)​​+0 at optimum∇x​f(x(θ),θ)⊤​​∂θ∂x​.
(35)

Since ∇xf=0\nabla_{\mathbf{x}} f = \mathbf{0}∇x​f=0 at the optimum, the second term vanishes:

∇θv(θ)=∇θf(x(θ),θ).\boxed{\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} v(\boldsymbol{\theta}) = \nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} f(\mathbf{x}(\boldsymbol{\theta}), \boldsymbol{\theta})}.∇θ​v(θ)=∇θ​f(x(θ),θ)​.
(36)

This results tells us that you can compute the derivative of the optimal value by treating the maximizer as constant. You don’t need to compute ∂x∂θ\frac{\partial \mathbf{x}}{\partial \boldsymbol{\theta}}∂θ∂x​.

In our Bellman collocation problem, [B(θ)]i=max⁡a{r(si,a)+γE[∑ℓθℓφℓ(s′)]}[\mathcal{B}(\theta)]_i = \max_a \{r(s_i, a) + \gamma \mathbb{E}[\sum_\ell \theta_\ell \varphi_\ell(s')]\}[B(θ)]i​=maxa​{r(si​,a)+γE[∑ℓ​θℓ​φℓ​(s′)]}. To compute ∂[B(θ)]i∂θj\frac{\partial [\mathcal{B}(\theta)]_i}{\partial \theta_j}∂θj​∂[B(θ)]i​​, we don’t need to figure out how ai∗(θ)a_i^*(\theta)ai∗​(θ) changes with θ\thetaθ. We just evaluate the gradient at the optimal action:

∂[B(θ)]i∂θj=γ∑s′p(s′∣si,ai∗(θ))φj(s′).\frac{\partial [\mathcal{B}(\theta)]_i}{\partial \theta_j} = \gamma \sum_{s'} p(s'|s_i, a_i^*(\theta)) \varphi_j(s').∂θj​∂[B(θ)]i​​=γs′∑​p(s′∣si​,ai∗​(θ))φj​(s′).
(37)

Important assumptions: fff is smooth, the maximizer is unique and in the interior (or constraints are smooth with stable active sets), and the first-order condition holds.

Specifically, let ai∗(θ)a_i^*(\theta)ai∗​(θ) denote the optimal action at collocation point sis_isi​ given coefficients θ\thetaθ:

ai∗(θ)∈argmax⁡a∈Asi{r(si,a)+γ∑k∈Sp(k∣si,a)∑ℓ=1nθℓφℓ(k)}.a_i^*(\theta) \in \operatorname{argmax}_{a \in \mathcal{A}_{s_i}} \left\{ r(s_i, a) + \gamma \sum_{k \in \mathcal{S}} p(k|s_i, a) \sum_{\ell=1}^n \theta_\ell \varphi_\ell(k) \right\}.ai∗​(θ)∈argmaxa∈Asi​​​{r(si​,a)+γk∈S∑​p(k∣si​,a)ℓ=1∑n​θℓ​φℓ​(k)}.
(38)

By the Envelope Theorem, we can compute the derivative by treating ai∗a_i^*ai∗​ as constant:

∂[B(θ)]i∂θj=γ∑k∈Sp(k∣si,ai∗(θ))φj(k).\frac{\partial [\mathcal{B}(\theta)]_i}{\partial \theta_j} = \gamma \sum_{k \in \mathcal{S}} p(k|s_i, a_i^*(\theta)) \varphi_j(k).∂θj​∂[B(θ)]i​​=γk∈S∑​p(k∣si​,ai∗​(θ))φj​(k).
(39)

This is simply the expected value of the jjj-th basis function at the next state, evaluated at the optimal action for the current coefficient vector.

Why the Envelope Theorem Works Here

The Envelope Theorem applies to value functions of optimization problems. For a problem V(θ)=max⁡xf(x,θ)V(\theta) = \max_x f(x, \theta)V(θ)=maxx​f(x,θ), the derivative with respect to the parameter θ\thetaθ is:

dVdθ=∂f∂θ(x∗(θ),θ),\frac{dV}{d\theta} = \frac{\partial f}{\partial \theta}(x^*(\theta), \theta),dθdV​=∂θ∂f​(x∗(θ),θ),
(40)

where x∗(θ)x^*(\theta)x∗(θ) is the optimal choice. We don’t need to account for ∂x∗∂θ\frac{\partial x^*}{\partial \theta}∂θ∂x∗​ because at the optimum, the first-order condition ∂f∂x=0\frac{\partial f}{\partial x} = 0∂x∂f​=0 makes that term vanish.

In our case, [B(θ)]i[\mathcal{B}(\theta)]_i[B(θ)]i​ is the value of maximizing over actions aaa, with θ\thetaθ playing the role of the parameter vector. The Envelope Theorem lets us compute ∂[B(θ)]i∂θj\frac{\partial [\mathcal{B}(\theta)]_i}{\partial \theta_j}∂θj​∂[B(θ)]i​​ by differentiating the objective (the Bellman right-hand side) with respect to θj\theta_jθj​ while holding the optimal action ai∗a_i^*ai∗​ fixed. Since θj\theta_jθj​ only appears in the continuation value ∑ℓθℓφℓ(k)\sum_{\ell} \theta_\ell \varphi_\ell(k)∑ℓ​θℓ​φℓ​(k), the derivative picks out the coefficient of θj\theta_jθj​, which is the expected basis function value.

This approach is equivalent to the semi-smooth Newton method mentioned earlier: we’re computing a generalized Jacobian by treating the optimal action as locally constant. As we converge to the solution, the optimal actions stabilize, and Newton’s method achieves superlinear convergence.

Newton’s method algorithm:

  1. Start with initial guess θ(0)\theta^{(0)}θ(0)

  2. For iteration k=0,1,2,…k = 0, 1, 2, \ldotsk=0,1,2,…:

    • Compute B(θ(k))\mathcal{B}(\theta^{(k)})B(θ(k)) and optimal actions ai∗(θ(k))a_i^*(\theta^{(k)})ai∗​(θ(k)) for all collocation points

    • Compute Jacobian entries: [JB]ij=γ∑s′∈Sp(s′∣si,ai∗(θ(k)))φj(s′)[J_{\mathcal{B}}]_{ij} = \gamma \sum_{s' \in \mathcal{S}} p(s'|s_i, a_i^*(\theta^{(k)})) \varphi_j(s')[JB​]ij​=γ∑s′∈S​p(s′∣si​,ai∗​(θ(k)))φj​(s′)

    • Update: θ(k+1)=θ(k)−[Φ−JB(θ(k))]−1[Φθ(k)−B(θ(k))]\theta^{(k+1)} = \theta^{(k)} - [\boldsymbol{\Phi} - J_{\mathcal{B}}(\theta^{(k)})]^{-1} [\boldsymbol{\Phi} \theta^{(k)} - \mathcal{B}(\theta^{(k)})]θ(k+1)=θ(k)−[Φ−JB​(θ(k))]−1[Φθ(k)−B(θ(k))]

    • Check convergence

This method offers quadratic convergence near the solution but requires a good initial guess. The Jacobian computation via the Envelope Theorem is typically cheaper than explicit semi-smooth calculus and has a clear economic interpretation: it tracks how the value propagates through the optimal decisions.

Comparison of Solution Methods¶

We now have two approaches to solving the collocation fixed-point equation Φθ=B(θ)\boldsymbol{\Phi} \theta = \mathcal{B}(\theta)Φθ=B(θ):

MethodFormulationConvergencePer-iteration costInitial guess sensitivity
Function iterationθ(k+1)=Φ−1B(θ(k))\theta^{(k+1)} = \boldsymbol{\Phi}^{-1} \mathcal{B}(\theta^{(k)})θ(k+1)=Φ−1B(θ(k))Linear (when contraction holds)Low (one linear solve)Robust
Newton’s methodθ(k+1)=θ(k)−[Φ−JB]−1[Φθ(k)−B(θ(k))]\theta^{(k+1)} = \theta^{(k)} - [\boldsymbol{\Phi} - J_{\mathcal{B}}]^{-1}[\boldsymbol{\Phi} \theta^{(k)} - \mathcal{B}(\theta^{(k)})]θ(k+1)=θ(k)−[Φ−JB​]−1[Φθ(k)−B(θ(k))]Quadratic (near solution)Moderate (Jacobian + linear solve)Requires good initial guess

Function iteration exploits the fixed-point structure directly, treating the collocation problem as value iteration in coefficient space. When the finite-dimensional approximation preserves the contraction property of the Bellman operator, it converges globally from any initial guess. Each iteration is cheap: evaluate the Bellman operator at nnn points (the collocation nodes) and solve one linear system Φθ(k+1)=B(θ(k))\boldsymbol{\Phi} \theta^{(k+1)} = \mathcal{B}(\theta^{(k)})Φθ(k+1)=B(θ(k)). However, convergence can be slow, especially when γ\gammaγ is close to 1.

Newton’s method treats the problem as rootfinding, exploiting smoothness (via the Envelope Theorem) to achieve fast local convergence. Once close to the solution, Newton’s method typically converges in just a few iterations. The per-iteration cost is higher: in addition to evaluating B(θ(k))\mathcal{B}(\theta^{(k)})B(θ(k)), we must compute the Jacobian JB(θ(k))J_{\mathcal{B}}(\theta^{(k)})JB​(θ(k)), which requires evaluating expected basis function values at all collocation points. However, Newton’s method is sensitive to initial conditions and may diverge or converge to spurious solutions when started far from the true fixed point.

Connection to Policy Iteration

The Newton update θ(k+1)=[Φ−JB(θ(k))]−1B(θ(k))\theta^{(k+1)} = [\boldsymbol{\Phi} - J_{\mathcal{B}}(\theta^{(k)})]^{-1} \mathcal{B}(\theta^{(k)})θ(k+1)=[Φ−JB​(θ(k))]−1B(θ(k)) is equivalent to the policy iteration algorithm commonly used in discrete-state dynamic programming. To see this, note that at the optimal coefficients θ∗\theta^*θ∗, we have Φθ∗=B(θ∗)\boldsymbol{\Phi} \theta^* = \mathcal{B}(\theta^*)Φθ∗=B(θ∗). The Newton step finds the coefficients that would be optimal if the policy (the optimal actions at each collocation point) were held fixed at the current iteration’s policy. This connection explains why Newton’s method often converges rapidly: like policy iteration, it implicitly performs policy evaluation and policy improvement, which can converge in just a few iterations for well-behaved problems.

Practical recommendations:

  1. For problems with strong contraction (small γ\gammaγ, well-conditioned Φ\boldsymbol{\Phi}Φ, shape-preserving bases): Start with function iteration. It’s simple, robust, and often converges adequately in 20-50 iterations.

  2. For problems with weak contraction (large γ\gammaγ, high-order polynomial bases): Use a hybrid approach:

    • Run function iteration for 5-10 iterations to get into the basin of attraction

    • Switch to Newton’s method for fast convergence to high accuracy

  3. For problems where contraction fails (non-monotone bases, approximation destroys contraction): Newton’s method may be necessary from the start, but requires careful initialization (e.g., from a coarser approximation).

  4. Quasi-Newton methods (like BFGS or Broyden) offer a middle ground: they approximate the Jacobian using function evaluations only, avoiding the Envelope Theorem calculation. This can be useful when computing JBJ_{\mathcal{B}}JB​ is expensive or when the Jacobian approximation is acceptable.

The choice often depends on the application domain. In economic models where the value function is guaranteed to be concave and monotone, simple bases (linear interpolation, shape-preserving splines) combined with function iteration are reliable. In control problems with complex dynamics, high-order approximations combined with Newton’s method may be necessary for accuracy.

Monotone Projection and the Preservation of Contraction¶

The informal discussion of shape preservation hints at a deeper theoretical question: when does the function iteration method converge? Recall from our discussion of collocation that function iteration proceeds in two steps:

  1. Apply the Bellman operator at collocation points: t(k)=v(θ(k))t^{(k)} = v(\theta^{(k)})t(k)=v(θ(k)) where ti(k)=Lv^(k)(si)t_i^{(k)} = \mathrm{L}\hat{v}^{(k)}(s_i)ti(k)​=Lv^(k)(si​)

  2. Fit new coefficients to match these targets: Φθ(k+1)=t(k)\boldsymbol{\Phi} \theta^{(k+1)} = t^{(k)}Φθ(k+1)=t(k), giving θ(k+1)=Φ−1v(θ(k))\theta^{(k+1)} = \boldsymbol{\Phi}^{-1} v(\theta^{(k)})θ(k+1)=Φ−1v(θ(k))

We can reinterpret this iteration in function space rather than coefficient space. Let Ψ\PsiΨ be the projection operator that takes any function fff and returns its approximation in span{φ1,…,φn}\text{span}\{\varphi_1, \ldots, \varphi_n\}span{φ1​,…,φn​}. For collocation, Ψ\PsiΨ is the interpolation operator: (Ψf)(s)(\Psi f)(s)(Ψf)(s) is the unique linear combination of basis functions that matches fff at the collocation points. Then Step 2 can be written as: fit v^(k+1)\hat{v}^{(k+1)}v^(k+1) so that v^(k+1)(si)=Lv^(k)(si)\hat{v}^{(k+1)}(s_i) = \mathrm{L}\hat{v}^{(k)}(s_i)v^(k+1)(si​)=Lv^(k)(si​) for all collocation points, which means v^(k+1)=Ψ(Lv^(k))\hat{v}^{(k+1)} = \Psi(\mathrm{L}\hat{v}^{(k)})v^(k+1)=Ψ(Lv^(k)).

In other words, function iteration is equivalent to projected value iteration in function space:

v^(k+1)=ΨLv^(k).\hat{v}^{(k+1)} = \Psi \mathrm{L} \hat{v}^{(k)}.v^(k+1)=ΨLv^(k).
(41)

We know that standard value iteration vk+1=Lvkv_{k+1} = \mathrm{L} v_kvk+1​=Lvk​ converges because L\mathrm{L}L is a γ\gammaγ-contraction in the sup norm. But now we’re iterating with the composed operator ΨL\Psi\mathrm{L}ΨL instead of L\mathrm{L}L alone.

This ΨL\Psi\mathrm{L}ΨL structure is not specific to collocation. It is inherent in all projection methods. The general pattern is always the same: apply the Bellman operator to get a target function Lv^(k)\mathrm{L}\hat{v}^{(k)}Lv^(k), then project it back onto our approximation space to get v^(k+1)\hat{v}^{(k+1)}v^(k+1). The projection step defines an operator Ψ\PsiΨ that depends on our choice of test functions:

  • For collocation, Ψ\PsiΨ interpolates values at collocation points

  • For Galerkin, Ψ\PsiΨ is orthogonal projection with respect to ⟨⋅,⋅⟩w\langle \cdot, \cdot \rangle_w⟨⋅,⋅⟩w​

  • For least squares, Ψ\PsiΨ minimizes the weighted residual norm

But regardless of which projection method we use, iteration takes the form v^(k+1)=ΨLv^(k)\hat{v}^{(k+1)} = \Psi\mathrm{L}\hat{v}^{(k)}v^(k+1)=ΨLv^(k).

The critical question is: does the composition ΨL\Psi \mathrm{L}ΨL inherit the contraction property of L\mathrm{L}L? If not, the iteration may diverge, oscillate, or converge to a spurious fixed point even though the original problem is well-posed.

Monotone Approximators and Stability¶

The answer turns out to depend on specific properties of the approximation operator Ψ\PsiΨ. This theory was developed independently across multiple research communities—computational economics Judd (1992)Judd (1996)Santos & Vigo-Aguiar (1998), economic dynamics Stachurski (2009), and reinforcement learning Gordon (1995)Gordon (1999)—arriving at essentially the same mathematical conditions.

Monotonicity Implies Nonexpansiveness¶

It turns out that approximation operators satisfying simple structural properties automatically preserve contraction.

Proposition 1 (Monotone operators are nonexpansive (Stachurski))

Let Ψ:B(S)→B(S)\Psi: B(\mathcal{S}) \to B(\mathcal{S})Ψ:B(S)→B(S) be a linear operator on the space of bounded functions. If Ψ\PsiΨ satisfies:

  1. Monotonicity: f≤gf \leq gf≤g pointwise implies Ψf≤Ψg\Psi f \leq \Psi gΨf≤Ψg

  2. Constant preservation: Ψ1=1\Psi\mathbf{1} = \mathbf{1}Ψ1=1 where 1\mathbf{1}1 is the constant function equal to 1

Then Ψ\PsiΨ is nonexpansive in the sup norm: ∥Ψf−Ψg∥∞≤∥f−g∥∞\|\Psi f - \Psi g\|_\infty \leq \|f - g\|_\infty∥Ψf−Ψg∥∞​≤∥f−g∥∞​ for all f,g∈B(S)f, g \in B(\mathcal{S})f,g∈B(S).

Proof 1

Let M=∥f−g∥∞M = \|f - g\|_\inftyM=∥f−g∥∞​. Then −M≤f(s)−g(s)≤M-M \leq f(s) - g(s) \leq M−M≤f(s)−g(s)≤M for all sss, which can be written as g−M1≤f≤g+M1g - M\mathbf{1} \leq f \leq g + M\mathbf{1}g−M1≤f≤g+M1. By monotonicity, Ψ(g−M1)≤Ψf≤Ψ(g+M1)\Psi(g - M\mathbf{1}) \leq \Psi f \leq \Psi(g + M\mathbf{1})Ψ(g−M1)≤Ψf≤Ψ(g+M1). By linearity and constant preservation, Ψg−M1≤Ψf≤Ψg+M1\Psi g - M\mathbf{1} \leq \Psi f \leq \Psi g + M\mathbf{1}Ψg−M1≤Ψf≤Ψg+M1, which means ∣Ψf(s)−Ψg(s)∣≤M|\Psi f(s) - \Psi g(s)| \leq M∣Ψf(s)−Ψg(s)∣≤M for all sss. Therefore ∥Ψf−Ψg∥∞≤∥f−g∥∞\|\Psi f - \Psi g\|_\infty \leq \|f - g\|_\infty∥Ψf−Ψg∥∞​≤∥f−g∥∞​.

This proposition shows that monotonicity and constant preservation automatically imply nonexpansiveness. There is no need to verify this separately. The intuition is that a monotone, constant-preserving operator acts like a weighted average that respects order structure and cannot amplify differences between functions.

Preservation of Contraction¶

Combining nonexpansiveness with the contraction property of the Bellman operator yields the main stability result.

Theorem 1 (Stability of projected value iteration (Santos-Vigo-Aguiar))

Let L:B(S)→B(S)\mathrm{L}: B(\mathcal{S}) \to B(\mathcal{S})L:B(S)→B(S) be a γ\gammaγ-contraction on the space of bounded functions with respect to the sup norm. Let Ψ:B(S)→B(S)\Psi: B(\mathcal{S}) \to B(\mathcal{S})Ψ:B(S)→B(S) be a linear approximation operator satisfying monotonicity and constant preservation.

Then the composed operator ΨL\Psi\mathrm{L}ΨL is a γ\gammaγ-contraction, and projected value iteration vk+1=ΨLvkv_{k+1} = \Psi\mathrm{L} v_kvk+1​=ΨLvk​ converges globally to a unique fixed point vΨ∈Range(Ψ)v_\Psi \in \text{Range}(\Psi)vΨ​∈Range(Ψ) with approximation error:

∥vΨ−v∗∥∞≤11−γ∥Ψv∗−v∗∥∞,\|v_\Psi - v^*\|_\infty \leq \frac{1}{1-\gamma} \|\Psi v^* - v^*\|_\infty,∥vΨ​−v∗∥∞​≤1−γ1​∥Ψv∗−v∗∥∞​,
(42)

where v∗v^*v∗ is the true value function.

Proof 2

Since L\mathrm{L}L is a γ\gammaγ-contraction, we have −γ∥f−g∥∞≤Lf−Lg≤γ∥f−g∥∞-\gamma\|f-g\|_\infty \leq \mathrm{L} f - \mathrm{L} g \leq \gamma\|f-g\|_\infty−γ∥f−g∥∞​≤Lf−Lg≤γ∥f−g∥∞​ pointwise. By monotonicity of Ψ\PsiΨ, Ψ(−γ∥f−g∥∞)≤Ψ(Lf−Lg)≤Ψ(γ∥f−g∥∞)\Psi(-\gamma\|f-g\|_\infty) \leq \Psi(\mathrm{L} f - \mathrm{L} g) \leq \Psi(\gamma\|f-g\|_\infty)Ψ(−γ∥f−g∥∞​)≤Ψ(Lf−Lg)≤Ψ(γ∥f−g∥∞​). By constant preservation, −γ∥f−g∥∞≤Ψ(Lf−Lg)≤γ∥f−g∥∞-\gamma\|f-g\|_\infty \leq \Psi(\mathrm{L} f - \mathrm{L} g) \leq \gamma\|f-g\|_\infty−γ∥f−g∥∞​≤Ψ(Lf−Lg)≤γ∥f−g∥∞​, which implies ∥ΨLf−ΨLg∥∞≤γ∥f−g∥∞\|\Psi\mathrm{L} f - \Psi\mathrm{L} g\|_\infty \leq \gamma\|f-g\|_\infty∥ΨLf−ΨLg∥∞​≤γ∥f−g∥∞​.

The error bound follows from fixed-point analysis: v∗−vΨ=(I−ΨL)−1(v∗−Ψv∗)v^* - v_\Psi = (I - \Psi\mathrm{L})^{-1}(v^* - \Psi v^*)v∗−vΨ​=(I−ΨL)−1(v∗−Ψv∗), and since ΨL\Psi\mathrm{L}ΨL is a γ\gammaγ-contraction, ∥(I−ΨL)−1∥≤(1−γ)−1\|(I - \Psi\mathrm{L})^{-1}\| \leq (1-\gamma)^{-1}∥(I−ΨL)−1∥≤(1−γ)−1.

This error bound tells us that the fixed-point error is controlled by how well Ψ\PsiΨ can represent v∗v^*v∗. If v∗∈Range(Ψ)v^* \in \text{Range}(\Psi)v∗∈Range(Ψ), then Ψv∗=v∗\Psi v^* = v^*Ψv∗=v∗ and the error vanishes. Otherwise, the error is proportional to the approximation error ∥Ψv∗−v∗∥∞\|\Psi v^* - v^*\|_\infty∥Ψv∗−v∗∥∞​, amplified by the factor (1−γ)−1(1-\gamma)^{-1}(1−γ)−1.

Averagers in Discrete-State Problems¶

For discrete-state problems, the monotonicity conditions have a natural interpretation as averaging with nonnegative weights. This characterization was developed by Gordon in the context of reinforcement learning.

Definition 1 (Averager (Gordon))

An operator Ψ:R∣S∣→R∣S∣\Psi: \mathbb{R}^{|\mathcal{S}|} \to \mathbb{R}^{|\mathcal{S}|}Ψ:R∣S∣→R∣S∣ is an averager if Ψv=Wv\Psi v = WvΨv=Wv where WWW is a ∣S∣×∣S∣|\mathcal{S}| \times |\mathcal{S}|∣S∣×∣S∣ stochastic matrix: wij≥0w_{ij} \geq 0wij​≥0 and ∑jwij=1\sum_j w_{ij} = 1∑j​wij​=1 for all iii.

Averagers automatically satisfy the monotonicity conditions: linearity follows from matrix multiplication, monotonicity follows from nonnegativity of entries, and constant preservation follows from row sums equaling one.

Theorem 2 (Stability with averagers (Gordon))

If Ψ\PsiΨ is an averager and L\mathrm{L}L is the Bellman operator (a γ\gammaγ-contraction), then ΨL\Psi\mathrm{L}ΨL is a γ\gammaγ-contraction, and value iteration vk+1=ΨLvkv_{k+1} = \Psi\mathrm{L} v_kvk+1​=ΨLvk​ converges to a unique fixed point.

This specializes the Santos-Vigo-Aguiar theorem to discrete states, expressed in the probabilistic language of stochastic matrices. The stochastic matrix characterization connects to Markov chain theory: Ψv\Psi vΨv represents expected values after one transition, and the monotonicity property reflects the fact that expectations preserve order.

Examples of averagers include state aggregation (averaging values within groups), K-nearest neighbors (averaging over nearest states), kernel smoothing with positive kernels, and multilinear interpolation on grids (barycentric weights are nonnegative and sum to one). Counterexamples include linear least squares regression (projection matrix may have negative entries) and high-order polynomial interpolation (Runge phenomenon produces negative weights).

Which Approximation Operators Are Monotone?¶

MethodMonotone?Notes
Piecewise linear interpolationYesAlways an averager; guaranteed stability
Multilinear interpolation (grid)YesBarycentric weights are nonnegative and sum to one
Shape-preserving splines (Schumaker)YesDesigned to maintain monotonicity
State aggregationYesExact averaging within groups
Kernel smoothing (positive kernels)YesIf kernel integrates to one
High-order polynomial interpolationNoOscillations violate monotonicity (Runge phenomenon)
Least squares projection (arbitrary basis)NoProjection matrix may have negative entries
Fourier/spectral methodsNoNot monotone-preserving in general
Neural networksNoHighly flexible but no monotonicity guarantees

The distinction between “safe” (monotone) and “potentially unstable” (non-monotone) approximators provides rigorous foundation for the folk wisdom that linear interpolation is reliable while high-order polynomials can be dangerous for value iteration.

Practical Implications¶

When using successive approximation (fixed-point iteration):

  • Choose monotone approximators to guarantee convergence

  • Piecewise linear interpolation, state aggregation, and kernel methods with positive kernels are safe choices

  • High-order polynomials and least squares regression may fail to converge even when the Bellman operator is a strong contraction

When using rootfinding methods (Newton):

  • Monotonicity is not required for convergence

  • Can use smooth approximations (polynomials, splines, neural networks) for better approximation quality

  • Requires good initial guesses and well-conditioned systems

  • Stability depends on numerical properties of the Jacobian, not contraction preservation

Hybrid strategies:

  1. Use smooth approximation for policy representation, but monotone averager for value iteration

  2. Regularize smooth approximations with monotonicity constraints (monotone neural networks)

  3. Run a few iterations with a monotone method to generate initial guess, then switch to Newton’s method with smooth approximation

  4. Solve projection equations directly (collocation with Newton) rather than iterating

This explains observed differences across research communities: reinforcement learning (traditionally using iterative TD methods) emphasized averagers, while computational economics (using collocation with Newton solvers) was more comfortable with polynomial bases.

Weighted Norms and Extensions¶

The monotone approximation theory provides complete characterization for contraction in the sup norm. Several important extensions remain active research areas:

Weighted L2L^2L2 norms: For policy evaluation with Galerkin projection, the relevant norm is ∥⋅∥ξ\|\cdot\|_\xi∥⋅∥ξ​ where ξ\xiξ is a state distribution. The contraction preservation condition becomes: ξ\xiξ must be stationary under the policy’s transition operator. On-policy TD methods converge while off-policy methods can diverge because the weighting distribution must match the policy dynamics.

Nonlinear approximation: Neural networks don’t fit the linear operator framework. Recent work on monotone and convex neural networks attempts to recover stability through architectural constraints, but a complete theory is still emerging.

High-dimensional state spaces: Grid-based averagers become intractable due to curse of dimensionality. Understanding which non-averaging approximations provide acceptable stability-accuracy trade-offs is crucial for modern applications.

Off-policy learning: The averager framework assumes on-policy evaluation. Off-policy methods require additional machinery (importance sampling, gradient corrections) to maintain stability, even with averaging operators.

Galerkin Projection and Least Squares Temporal Difference¶

An important special case emerges when we apply Galerkin projection to the policy evaluation problem rather than the optimality problem. For a fixed policy π\piπ, the policy evaluation Bellman equation is:

vπ(s)=Lπvπ(s)=r(s,π(s))+γ∑s′∈Sp(s′∣s,π(s))vπ(s′).v^\pi(s) = \mathrm{L}_\pi v^\pi(s) = r(s,\pi(s)) + \gamma \sum_{s' \in \mathcal{S}} p(s'|s,\pi(s)) v^\pi(s').vπ(s)=Lπ​vπ(s)=r(s,π(s))+γs′∈S∑​p(s′∣s,π(s))vπ(s′).
(43)

This is a linear operator (no max), making the projection problem significantly simpler. Consider a linear function approximation v^(s)=φ(s)⊤θ\hat{v}(s) = \boldsymbol{\varphi}(s)^\top \boldsymbol{\theta}v^(s)=φ(s)⊤θ where φ(s)=[φ1(s),…,φn(s)]⊤\boldsymbol{\varphi}(s) = [\varphi_1(s), \ldots, \varphi_n(s)]^\topφ(s)=[φ1​(s),…,φn​(s)]⊤ are basis functions and θ=[θ1,…,θn]⊤\boldsymbol{\theta} = [\theta_1, \ldots, \theta_n]^\topθ=[θ1​,…,θn​]⊤ are coefficients to determine. The residual is:

R(s;θ)=Lπv^(s)−v^(s)=r(s,π(s))+γ∑s′p(s′∣s,π(s))φ(s′)⊤θ−φ(s)⊤θ.R(s; \boldsymbol{\theta}) = \mathrm{L}_\pi \hat{v}(s) - \hat{v}(s) = r(s,\pi(s)) + \gamma \sum_{s'} p(s'|s,\pi(s)) \boldsymbol{\varphi}(s')^\top \boldsymbol{\theta} - \boldsymbol{\varphi}(s)^\top \boldsymbol{\theta}.R(s;θ)=Lπ​v^(s)−v^(s)=r(s,π(s))+γs′∑​p(s′∣s,π(s))φ(s′)⊤θ−φ(s)⊤θ.
(44)

The Galerkin projection requires the residual to be orthogonal to all basis functions with respect to some weighting:

∑s∈Sξ(s)R(s;θ)φj(s)=0,j=1,…,n,\sum_{s \in \mathcal{S}} \xi(s) R(s; \boldsymbol{\theta}) \varphi_j(s) = 0, \quad j = 1, \ldots, n,s∈S∑​ξ(s)R(s;θ)φj​(s)=0,j=1,…,n,
(45)

where ξ(s)\xi(s)ξ(s) is a distribution over states (often the stationary distribution under policy π\piπ, or uniform over visited states). Substituting the residual:

∑sξ(s)[r(s,π(s))+γ∑s′p(s′∣s,π(s))φ(s′)⊤θ−φ(s)⊤θ]φj(s)=0.\sum_s \xi(s) \left[ r(s,\pi(s)) + \gamma \sum_{s'} p(s'|s,\pi(s)) \boldsymbol{\varphi}(s')^\top \boldsymbol{\theta} - \boldsymbol{\varphi}(s)^\top \boldsymbol{\theta} \right] \varphi_j(s) = 0.s∑​ξ(s)[r(s,π(s))+γs′∑​p(s′∣s,π(s))φ(s′)⊤θ−φ(s)⊤θ]φj​(s)=0.
(46)

Rearranging and writing in matrix form, let Ξ\boldsymbol{\Xi}Ξ be a diagonal matrix with Ξss=ξ(s)\Xi_{ss} = \xi(s)Ξss​=ξ(s), Φ\boldsymbol{\Phi}Φ be the ∣S∣×n|\mathcal{S}| \times n∣S∣×n matrix with rows φ(s)⊤\boldsymbol{\varphi}(s)^\topφ(s)⊤, and Pπ\mathbf{P}_\piPπ​ be the transition matrix under policy π\piπ. The Galerkin conditions become:

Φ⊤Ξ(rπ+γPπΦθ−Φθ)=0.\boldsymbol{\Phi}^\top \boldsymbol{\Xi} (\mathbf{r}_\pi + \gamma \mathbf{P}_\pi \boldsymbol{\Phi} \boldsymbol{\theta} - \boldsymbol{\Phi} \boldsymbol{\theta}) = \mathbf{0}.Φ⊤Ξ(rπ​+γPπ​Φθ−Φθ)=0.
(47)

Solving for θ\boldsymbol{\theta}θ:

Φ⊤Ξ(Φ−γPπΦ)θ=Φ⊤Ξrπ.\boldsymbol{\Phi}^\top \boldsymbol{\Xi} (\boldsymbol{\Phi} - \gamma \mathbf{P}_\pi \boldsymbol{\Phi}) \boldsymbol{\theta} = \boldsymbol{\Phi}^\top \boldsymbol{\Xi} \mathbf{r}_\pi.Φ⊤Ξ(Φ−γPπ​Φ)θ=Φ⊤Ξrπ​.
(48)

We have just derived the Least Squares Temporal Difference (LSTD) solution for policy evaluation. This shows that LSTD is Galerkin projection applied to the linear policy evaluation Bellman equation. The “least squares” name comes from the fact that this is the projection (in the weighted ℓ2\ell^2ℓ2 sense) of the Bellman operator’s output onto the span of the basis functions.

The projection perspective makes clear an important aspect of approximate dynamic programming. The solution θ\boldsymbol{\theta}θ does not satisfy the true Bellman equation v=Lπvv = \mathrm{L}_\pi vv=Lπ​v (which is typically impossible within our finite-dimensional approximation space). Instead, it satisfies v^=ΠLπv^\hat{v} = \Pi \mathrm{L}_\pi \hat{v}v^=ΠLπ​v^, where Π\PiΠ is the projection operator onto span{φ1,…,φn}\text{span}\{\varphi_1, \ldots, \varphi_n\}span{φ1​,…,φn​}. We find the fixed point of the projected Bellman operator, not the Bellman operator itself. This is why approximation error persists even at convergence: the best we can do is find the value function whose Bellman operator output projects back onto itself.

The Projected Bellman Equations¶

The LSTD solution gives a closed-form expression and connects to iterative algorithms developed in the next chapter. Understanding convergence of these methods requires analyzing when the projected Bellman operator ΠLπ\Pi \mathrm{L}_\piΠLπ​ is a contraction.

Norms and projections. Fix a feature matrix Φ∈R∣S∣×n\boldsymbol{\Phi} \in \mathbb{R}^{|\mathcal{S}| \times n}Φ∈R∣S∣×n with full column rank and a probability distribution ξ\xiξ over states. Define the ξ\xiξ-weighted inner product and norm by

⟨u,v⟩ξ:=∑sξ(s)u(s)v(s)=u⊤Ξv,∥v∥ξ:=v⊤Ξv,\langle u, v \rangle_\xi := \sum_s \xi(s) u(s) v(s) = u^\top \boldsymbol{\Xi} v, \qquad \|v\|_\xi := \sqrt{v^\top \boldsymbol{\Xi} v},⟨u,v⟩ξ​:=s∑​ξ(s)u(s)v(s)=u⊤Ξv,∥v∥ξ​:=v⊤Ξv​,
(49)

where Ξ=diag(ξ)\boldsymbol{\Xi} = \text{diag}(\xi)Ξ=diag(ξ). The orthogonal projection onto span(Φ)\text{span}(\boldsymbol{\Phi})span(Φ) with respect to ⟨⋅,⋅⟩ξ\langle \cdot, \cdot \rangle_\xi⟨⋅,⋅⟩ξ​ is

Π=Φ(Φ⊤ΞΦ)−1Φ⊤Ξ.\Pi = \boldsymbol{\Phi}(\boldsymbol{\Phi}^\top \boldsymbol{\Xi} \boldsymbol{\Phi})^{-1} \boldsymbol{\Phi}^\top \boldsymbol{\Xi}.Π=Φ(Φ⊤ΞΦ)−1Φ⊤Ξ.
(50)

An operator T\mathrm{T}T is a β\betaβ-contraction in norm ∥⋅∥\|\cdot\|∥⋅∥ if ∥Tv−Tw∥≤β∥v−w∥\|\mathrm{T}v - \mathrm{T}w\| \leq \beta \|v - w\|∥Tv−Tw∥≤β∥v−w∥ for all v,wv, wv,w and some β<1\beta < 1β<1. It is a non-expansion if the same holds with β=1\beta = 1β=1.

Why Π\PiΠ is a non-expansion. This follows from the Pythagorean identity in weighted inner product spaces. For any u∈R∣S∣u \in \mathbb{R}^{|\mathcal{S}|}u∈R∣S∣, the projection Πu\Pi uΠu and the residual (I−Π)u(I - \Pi)u(I−Π)u are ξ\xiξ-orthogonal: ⟨Πu,(I−Π)u⟩ξ=0\langle \Pi u, (I-\Pi)u \rangle_\xi = 0⟨Πu,(I−Π)u⟩ξ​=0. Therefore,

∥u∥ξ2=∥Πu∥ξ2+∥(I−Π)u∥ξ2.\|u\|_\xi^2 = \|\Pi u\|_\xi^2 + \|(I-\Pi)u\|_\xi^2.∥u∥ξ2​=∥Πu∥ξ2​+∥(I−Π)u∥ξ2​.
(51)

Applying this to u−vu - vu−v gives

∥Πu−Πv∥ξ2=∥Π(u−v)∥ξ2≤∥Π(u−v)∥ξ2+∥(I−Π)(u−v)∥ξ2=∥u−v∥ξ2,\|\Pi u - \Pi v\|_\xi^2 = \|\Pi(u-v)\|_\xi^2 \leq \|\Pi(u-v)\|_\xi^2 + \|(I-\Pi)(u-v)\|_\xi^2 = \|u - v\|_\xi^2,∥Πu−Πv∥ξ2​=∥Π(u−v)∥ξ2​≤∥Π(u−v)∥ξ2​+∥(I−Π)(u−v)∥ξ2​=∥u−v∥ξ2​,
(52)

proving ∥Πu−Πv∥ξ≤∥u−v∥ξ\|\Pi u - \Pi v\|_\xi \leq \|u - v\|_\xi∥Πu−Πv∥ξ​≤∥u−v∥ξ​.

When is Lπ\mathrm{L}_\piLπ​ a contraction in ∥⋅∥ξ\|\cdot\|_\xi∥⋅∥ξ​? Write the policy evaluation operator as Lπv=rπ+γPπv\mathrm{L}_\pi v = r_\pi + \gamma \mathbf{P}_\pi vLπ​v=rπ​+γPπ​v, where Pπ\mathbf{P}_\piPπ​ is the transition matrix under policy π\piπ. We know Lπ\mathrm{L}_\piLπ​ is a γ\gammaγ-contraction in ∥⋅∥∞\|\cdot\|_\infty∥⋅∥∞​ from earlier chapters. However, whether it contracts in ∥⋅∥ξ\|\cdot\|_\xi∥⋅∥ξ​ depends on the relationship between ξ\xiξ and Pπ\mathbf{P}_\piPπ​.

We need to establish when the stochastic matrix Pπ\mathbf{P}_\piPπ​ is non-expansive in ∥⋅∥ξ\|\cdot\|_\xi∥⋅∥ξ​. Following Bertsekas (Lemma 6.3.1), suppose ξ\xiξ is a steady-state probability vector for Pπ\mathbf{P}_\piPπ​ with positive components, meaning:

ξ⊤Pπ=ξ⊤,or equivalently,ξ(s′)=∑sξ(s)p(s′∣s,π(s)) for all s′.\xi^\top \mathbf{P}_\pi = \xi^\top, \qquad \text{or equivalently,} \qquad \xi(s') = \sum_s \xi(s) p(s'|s,\pi(s)) \text{ for all } s'.ξ⊤Pπ​=ξ⊤,or equivalently,ξ(s′)=s∑​ξ(s)p(s′∣s,π(s)) for all s′.
(53)

Then for any z∈R∣S∣z \in \mathbb{R}^{|\mathcal{S}|}z∈R∣S∣, using the convexity of the square function (Jensen’s inequality):

∥Pπz∥ξ2=∑sξ(s)(∑s′p(s′∣s,π(s))z(s′))2≤∑sξ(s)∑s′p(s′∣s,π(s))z(s′)2=∑s′(∑sξ(s)p(s′∣s,π(s)))z(s′)2\begin{align*} \|\mathbf{P}_\pi z\|_\xi^2 &= \sum_s \xi(s) \left(\sum_{s'} p(s'|s,\pi(s)) z(s')\right)^2 \\ &\leq \sum_s \xi(s) \sum_{s'} p(s'|s,\pi(s)) z(s')^2 \\ &= \sum_{s'} \left(\sum_s \xi(s) p(s'|s,\pi(s))\right) z(s')^2 \end{align*}∥Pπ​z∥ξ2​​=s∑​ξ(s)(s′∑​p(s′∣s,π(s))z(s′))2≤s∑​ξ(s)s′∑​p(s′∣s,π(s))z(s′)2=s′∑​(s∑​ξ(s)p(s′∣s,π(s)))z(s′)2​
(54)

Using the defining property of steady-state probabilities ∑sξ(s)p(s′∣s,π(s))=ξ(s′)\sum_s \xi(s) p(s'|s,\pi(s)) = \xi(s')∑s​ξ(s)p(s′∣s,π(s))=ξ(s′):

=∑s′ξ(s′)z(s′)2=∥z∥ξ2.= \sum_{s'} \xi(s') z(s')^2 = \|z\|_\xi^2.=s′∑​ξ(s′)z(s′)2=∥z∥ξ2​.
(55)

Therefore ∥Pπz∥ξ≤∥z∥ξ\|\mathbf{P}_\pi z\|_\xi \leq \|z\|_\xi∥Pπ​z∥ξ​≤∥z∥ξ​, showing that Pπ\mathbf{P}_\piPπ​ is non-expansive in ∥⋅∥ξ\|\cdot\|_\xi∥⋅∥ξ​. Since ∥Lπv−Lπw∥ξ=γ∥Pπ(v−w)∥ξ\|\mathrm{L}_\pi v - \mathrm{L}_\pi w\|_\xi = \gamma \|\mathbf{P}_\pi(v-w)\|_\xi∥Lπ​v−Lπ​w∥ξ​=γ∥Pπ​(v−w)∥ξ​:

∥Lπv−Lπw∥ξ≤γ∥v−w∥ξ.\|\mathrm{L}_\pi v - \mathrm{L}_\pi w\|_\xi \leq \gamma \|v - w\|_\xi.∥Lπ​v−Lπ​w∥ξ​≤γ∥v−w∥ξ​.
(56)

Thus Lπ\mathrm{L}_\piLπ​ is a γ\gammaγ-contraction in ∥⋅∥ξ\|\cdot\|_\xi∥⋅∥ξ​ when ξ\xiξ is the steady-state distribution of π\piπ.

Contraction of the composition. Combining our two results: Π\PiΠ is a non-expansion and (under stationarity) Lπ\mathrm{L}_\piLπ​ is a γ\gammaγ-contraction in ∥⋅∥ξ\|\cdot\|_\xi∥⋅∥ξ​. Therefore,

∥ΠLπv−ΠLπw∥ξ≤∥Lπv−Lπw∥ξ≤γ∥v−w∥ξ.\|\Pi \mathrm{L}_\pi v - \Pi \mathrm{L}_\pi w\|_\xi \leq \|\mathrm{L}_\pi v - \mathrm{L}_\pi w\|_\xi \leq \gamma \|v - w\|_\xi.∥ΠLπ​v−ΠLπ​w∥ξ​≤∥Lπ​v−Lπ​w∥ξ​≤γ∥v−w∥ξ​.
(57)

By the Banach fixed-point theorem, ΠLπ\Pi \mathrm{L}_\piΠLπ​ has a unique fixed point in R∣S∣\mathbb{R}^{|\mathcal{S}|}R∣S∣, and iterates vk+1=ΠLπvkv_{k+1} = \Pi \mathrm{L}_\pi v_kvk+1​=ΠLπ​vk​ converge to it from any v0v_0v0​. This fixed point satisfies the projected Bellman equation

v=Π(rπ+γPπv),v∈span(Φ).v = \Pi(r_\pi + \gamma \mathbf{P}_\pi v), \qquad v \in \text{span}(\boldsymbol{\Phi}).v=Π(rπ​+γPπ​v),v∈span(Φ).
(58)

Writing v=Φθv = \boldsymbol{\Phi} \boldsymbol{\theta}v=Φθ and left-multiplying by Φ⊤Ξ\boldsymbol{\Phi}^\top \boldsymbol{\Xi}Φ⊤Ξ yields the normal equations

Φ⊤Ξ(Φ−γPπΦ)θ=Φ⊤Ξrπ,\boldsymbol{\Phi}^\top \boldsymbol{\Xi}(\boldsymbol{\Phi} - \gamma \mathbf{P}_\pi \boldsymbol{\Phi}) \boldsymbol{\theta} = \boldsymbol{\Phi}^\top \boldsymbol{\Xi} r_\pi,Φ⊤Ξ(Φ−γPπ​Φ)θ=Φ⊤Ξrπ​,
(59)

which are precisely the LSTD equations we derived earlier. This result provides the theoretical foundation for temporal difference learning with linear function approximation: when learning on-policy (so ξ\xiξ is stationary), convergence is guaranteed.

Off-policy instability. When ξ\xiξ is not stationary for Pπ\mathbf{P}_\piPπ​ (as occurs when data come from a different behavior policy), the Jensen argument breaks down. The transition operator Pπ\mathbf{P}_\piPπ​ need not be non-expansive in ∥⋅∥ξ\|\cdot\|_\xi∥⋅∥ξ​, so ΠLπ\Pi \mathrm{L}_\piΠLπ​ may fail to be a contraction. This is the root cause of off-policy divergence phenomena in linear TD learning (e.g., Baird’s counterexample). Importance weighting and other corrections are designed to restore stability in this regime.

The linearity of the policy evaluation operator Lπ\mathrm{L}_\piLπ​ is what gives us the closed-form solution. We could apply Galerkin projection to the Bellman optimality equation v∗=Lv∗v^* = \mathrm{L} v^*v∗=Lv∗, setting up orthogonality conditions ∑sξ(s)R(s;θ)φj(s)=0\sum_s \xi(s) R(s; \boldsymbol{\theta}) \varphi_j(s) = 0∑s​ξ(s)R(s;θ)φj​(s)=0. The max operator makes these conditions nonlinear in θ\boldsymbol{\theta}θ, eliminating the closed form and requiring iterative solution. This brings us back to the successive approximation methods discussed earlier for collocation.

Fitted-Value Iteration: Beyond Linear Projection¶

Throughout this chapter, we have focused on polynomial approximations and linear projections, where the value function is represented as v(s)=∑j=1dθjφj(s)v(s) = \sum_{j=1}^d \theta_j \varphi_j(s)v(s)=∑j=1d​θj​φj​(s) and the projection operator Π\PiΠ solves a linear system to find the best coefficients θ\boldsymbol{\theta}θ. This framework, while analytically tractable, is just one instance of a much more general pattern that encompasses modern function approximation methods including neural networks, decision trees, kernel methods, and ensemble models.

The projection operator Π\PiΠ need not be a linear projection at all. Instead, it can be any computational procedure that fits an approximator to target data. This generalization leads us to fitted-value iteration (FVI), a universal template for approximate dynamic programming that subsumes classical projection methods as special cases while extending naturally to black-box function approximators.

The Fitting Operator¶

Rather than thinking of Π\PiΠ as a mathematical projection onto a subspace, we can view it as a fitting operator fit\mathtt{fit}fit that takes a dataset of state-value pairs {(si,yi)}i=1n\{(s_i, y_i)\}_{i=1}^n{(si​,yi​)}i=1n​ and produces a function v^∈F\hat{v} \in \mathcal{F}v^∈F from some hypothesis class F\mathcal{F}F:

v^=fit({(si,yi)}i=1n;F).\hat{v} = \mathtt{fit}\big(\{(s_i, y_i)\}_{i=1}^n; \mathcal{F}\big).v^=fit({(si​,yi​)}i=1n​;F).
(60)

The specifics of fit\mathtt{fit}fit depend on the function approximator:

  • Linear basis functions: fit\mathtt{fit}fit solves the weighted least-squares problem min⁡θ∑i=1nξ(si)(yi−∑jθjφj(si))2\min_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \sum_{i=1}^n \xi(s_i) \big(y_i - \sum_j \theta_j \varphi_j(s_i)\big)^2minθ​∑i=1n​ξ(si​)(yi​−∑j​θj​φj​(si​))2, yielding the Galerkin projection we studied earlier.

  • Neural networks: fit\mathtt{fit}fit runs stochastic gradient descent to minimize the loss L(θ)=∑i=1n(yi−vθ(si))2\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) = \sum_{i=1}^n (y_i - v_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(s_i))^2L(θ)=∑i=1n​(yi​−vθ​(si​))2, where vθv_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}vθ​ is a neural network with parameters θ\boldsymbol{\theta}θ.

  • Decision trees: fit\mathtt{fit}fit constructs a regression tree by recursively partitioning the state space to minimize the sum of squared residuals within each leaf.

  • Kernel methods: fit\mathtt{fit}fit computes kernel weights αi\alpha_iαi​ such that v^(s)=∑i=1nαik(s,si)\hat{v}(s) = \sum_{i=1}^n \alpha_i k(s, s_i)v^(s)=∑i=1n​αi​k(s,si​) for some kernel function kkk.

  • Ensemble methods: fit\mathtt{fit}fit trains multiple base learners (e.g., via boosting or bagging) and combines their predictions.

In each case, fit\mathtt{fit}fit maps a training dataset to a function, but the internal mechanism varies widely: closed-form solution, iterative optimization, tree construction, or ensemble aggregation.

Fitted-Value Iteration as Successive Approximation¶
