Fitted-value iteration is the natural extension of the successive approximation methods we examined earlier. Starting from an initial approximation v0∈Fv_0 \in \mathcal{F}v0​∈F, we iterate:

  1. Apply the Bellman operator at sample states {si}i=1n\{s_i\}_{i=1}^n{si​}i=1n​ to compute target values:

    yi=(Lvk)(si)=max⁡a∈A{r(si,a)+γ∑s′p(s′∣si,a)vk(s′)}.y_i = (\mathrm{L} v_k)(s_i) = \max_{a \in \mathcal{A}} \bigg\{ r(s_i, a) + \gamma \sum_{s'} p(s' \mid s_i, a) v_k(s') \bigg\}.yi​=(Lvk​)(si​)=a∈Amax​{r(si​,a)+γs′∑​p(s′∣si​,a)vk​(s′)}.
    (61)

  2. Fit a new approximation to the targets using the fitting operator:

    vk+1=fit({(si,yi)}i=1n;F).v_{k+1} = \mathtt{fit}\big(\{(s_i, y_i)\}_{i=1}^n; \mathcal{F}\big).vk+1​=fit({(si​,yi​)}i=1n​;F).
    (62)

This two-step rhythm (operator application followed by function fitting) mirrors exactly the structure of projected value iteration, where we computed ΠLvk\Pi \mathrm{L} v_kΠLvk​. The difference is that Π\PiΠ has been replaced by the more general fit\mathtt{fit}fit, which need not be a linear projection and need not have a closed form.

Algorithm 1 (Fitted-Value Iteration)

Inputs: Finite state set S\mathcal{S}S (or sample {si}i=1n\{s_i\}_{i=1}^n{si​}i=1n​), discount factor γ\gammaγ, function class F\mathcal{F}F, fitting procedure fit\mathtt{fit}fit, convergence tolerance ϵ\epsilonϵ

Output: Approximate value function v^≈v∗\hat{v} \approx v^*v^≈v∗

  1. Initialize v0∈Fv_0 \in \mathcal{F}v0​∈F arbitrarily

  2. Set k←0k \leftarrow 0k←0

  3. repeat

  4. \quad for each state si∈Ss_i \in \mathcal{S}si​∈S do

  5. \quad\quad Compute target: yi←max⁡a∈A{r(si,a)+γ∑s′p(s′∣si,a)vk(s′)}y_i \leftarrow \displaystyle\max_{a \in \mathcal{A}} \Big\{ r(s_i, a) + \gamma \sum_{s'} p(s' \mid s_i, a) v_k(s') \Big\}yi​←a∈Amax​{r(si​,a)+γs′∑​p(s′∣si​,a)vk​(s′)}

  6. \quad end for

  7. \quad Fit new approximation: vk+1←fit({(si,yi)}i=1n;F)v_{k+1} \leftarrow \mathtt{fit}\big(\{(s_i, y_i)\}_{i=1}^n; \mathcal{F}\big)vk+1​←fit({(si​,yi​)}i=1n​;F)

  8. \quad k←k+1k \leftarrow k+1k←k+1

  9. until ∥vk−vk−1∥<ϵ\|v_k - v_{k-1}\| < \epsilon∥vk​−vk−1​∥<ϵ (or maximum iterations reached)

  10. return vkv_kvk​

The abstraction fit\mathtt{fit}fit encapsulates all the complexity of function approximation, whether that involves solving a linear system, running gradient descent for thousands of steps, growing a decision tree, or training an ensemble. From the algorithmic perspective, these are simply different implementations of the same conceptual operation: mapping a dataset to a function.

Connection to the Projection Framework¶

How does fitted-value iteration relate to the projection methods we studied? The connection becomes clear when we recognize that the projection operator Π\PiΠ from earlier sections is simply one particular instantiation of fit\mathtt{fit}fit:

  • When F\mathcal{F}F is a linear subspace spanned by basis functions {φj}j=1d\{\varphi_j\}_{j=1}^d{φj​}j=1d​, and fit\mathtt{fit}fit minimizes the weighted squared error ∑iξ(si)(yi−∑jθjφj(si))2\sum_i \xi(s_i)(y_i - \sum_j \theta_j \varphi_j(s_i))^2∑i​ξ(si​)(yi​−∑j​θj​φj​(si​))2, then fit\mathtt{fit}fit coincides exactly with the Galerkin projection Π\PiΠ.

  • The collocation method emerges when we choose evaluation points {si}i=1d\{s_i\}_{i=1}^d{si​}i=1d​ equal in number to the basis functions and fit\mathtt{fit}fit enforces exact interpolation: ∑jθjφj(si)=yi\sum_j \theta_j \varphi_j(s_i) = y_i∑j​θj​φj​(si​)=yi​ for all iii.

  • Least-squares temporal difference (LSTD) methods, which we will encounter in the next chapter, can be viewed as performing fit\mathtt{fit}fit on data collected from simulation rather than the full state space.

The residual function R(s;θ)=v(s;θ)−(Lv(⋅;θ))(s)R(s; \boldsymbol{\theta}) = v(s; \boldsymbol{\theta}) - (\mathrm{L} v(\cdot; \boldsymbol{\theta}))(s)R(s;θ)=v(s;θ)−(Lv(⋅;θ))(s) still governs approximation quality. In the linear case, we minimized ∑sξ(s)R(s;θ)2\sum_s \xi(s) R(s; \boldsymbol{\theta})^2∑s​ξ(s)R(s;θ)2 by setting up orthogonality conditions. For nonlinear approximators, the residual remains the fundamental object of interest, but we typically cannot enforce orthogonality analytically. Instead, fit\mathtt{fit}fit implicitly seeks to make the residual small in an empirical sense over the training data.

Linear basis function approximation has many virtues: closed-form solutions, theoretical tractability, and well-understood convergence properties. But polynomial and radial basis functions require hand-crafted features, which can be difficult to design for high-dimensional state spaces or complex value function geometry. Neural networks, decision trees, kernel methods, and ensemble models can learn representations automatically or adapt their complexity to the data. The price is that we lose closed-form solutions and convergence guarantees, trading theoretical tractability for representational flexibility.

Toward Simulation-Based Methods¶

A limitation of the fitted-value iteration algorithm as presented is that it assumes we can evaluate the Bellman operator exactly at every state. That is, computing yi=(Lvk)(si)y_i = (\mathrm{L} v_k)(s_i)yi​=(Lvk​)(si​) requires knowing the transition probabilities p(j∣si,a)p(j \mid s_i, a)p(j∣si​,a) and being able to sum or integrate over all possible next states jjj.

In many real-world problems, we have neither. We might have access only to a simulator that generates sample transitions (s,a,r,j)(s, a, r, j)(s,a,r,j), or to a dataset of observed trajectories. We might not even know the full state space in advance. This brings us to the threshold of simulation-based approximate dynamic programming and reinforcement learning, where the Bellman operator must be approximated from samples rather than computed exactly.

The projection and collocation methods developed in this chapter provide the conceptual foundation for these simulation-based methods. The residual R(s;θ)=v(s;θ)−(Lv(⋅;θ))(s)R(s; \boldsymbol{\theta}) = v(s; \boldsymbol{\theta}) - (\mathrm{L} v(\cdot; \boldsymbol{\theta}))(s)R(s;θ)=v(s;θ)−(Lv(⋅;θ))(s) remains the central object. But instead of enforcing orthogonality conditions on the full state space, we will minimize empirical residuals on sampled data. The fitting operator fit\mathtt{fit}fit will take in noisy, incomplete samples rather than exact values. And convergence will be probabilistic, characterized by sample complexity rather than deterministic fixed-point theorems.

The next chapter introduces Monte Carlo integration and temporal-difference learning, showing how to estimate the expectations in the Bellman operator from simulated experience. Together with the fitted-value iteration framework developed here, these tools form the backbone of modern approximate dynamic programming, connecting classical numerical methods to the data-driven paradigm of reinforcement learning.
